45# The axes module contains all the wrappers to plotting functions. 

46# All the other methods should go in the _AxesBase class. 

47 

48 

49@_docstring.interpd 

50class Axes(_AxesBase): 

51 """ 

52 An Axes object encapsulates all the elements of an individual (sub-)plot in 

53 a figure. 

54 

55 It contains most of the (sub-)plot elements: `~.axis.Axis`, 

56 `~.axis.Tick`, `~.lines.Line2D`, `~.text.Text`, `~.patches.Polygon`, etc., 

57 and sets the coordinate system. 

58 

59 Like all visible elements in a figure, Axes is an `.Artist` subclass. 

60 

61 The `Axes` instance supports callbacks through a callbacks attribute which 

62 is a `~.cbook.CallbackRegistry` instance. The events you can connect to 

63 are 'xlim_changed' and 'ylim_changed' and the callback will be called with 

64 func(*ax*) where *ax* is the `Axes` instance. 

65 

66 .. note:: 

67 

68 As a user, you do not instantiate Axes directly, but use Axes creation 

69 methods instead; e.g. from `.pyplot` or `.Figure`: 

70 `~.pyplot.subplots`, `~.pyplot.subplot_mosaic` or `.Figure.add_axes`. 

71 

72 Attributes 

73 ---------- 

74 dataLim : `.Bbox` 

75 The bounding box enclosing all data displayed in the Axes. 

76 viewLim : `.Bbox` 

77 The view limits in data coordinates. 

78 

79 """ 

80 ### Labelling, legend and texts 

81 

82 def get_title(self, loc="center"): 

83 """ 

84 Get an Axes title. 

85 

86 Get one of the three available Axes titles. The available titles 

87 are positioned above the Axes in the center, flush with the left 

88 edge, and flush with the right edge. 

89 

90 Parameters 

91 ---------- 

92 loc : {'center', 'left', 'right'}, str, default: 'center' 

93 Which title to return. 

94 

95 Returns 

96 ------- 

97 str 

98 The title text string. 

99 

100 """ 

101 titles = {'left': self._left_title, 

102 'center': self.title, 

103 'right': self._right_title} 

104 title = _api.check_getitem(titles, loc=loc.lower()) 

105 return title.get_text() 

106 

107 def set_title(self, label, fontdict=None, loc=None, pad=None, *, y=None, 

108 **kwargs): 

109 """ 

110 Set a title for the Axes. 

111 

112 Set one of the three available Axes titles. The available titles 

113 are positioned above the Axes in the center, flush with the left 

114 edge, and flush with the right edge. 

115 

116 Parameters 

117 ---------- 

118 label : str 

119 Text to use for the title 

120 

121 fontdict : dict 

122 A dictionary controlling the appearance of the title text, 

123 the default *fontdict* is:: 

124 

125 {'fontsize': rcParams['axes.titlesize'], 

126 'fontweight': rcParams['axes.titleweight'], 

127 'color': rcParams['axes.titlecolor'], 

128 'verticalalignment': 'baseline', 

129 'horizontalalignment': loc} 

130 

131 loc : {'center', 'left', 'right'}, default: :rc:`axes.titlelocation` 

132 Which title to set. 

133 

134 y : float, default: :rc:`axes.titley` 

135 Vertical Axes location for the title (1.0 is the top). If 

136 None (the default) and :rc:`axes.titley` is also None, y is 

137 determined automatically to avoid decorators on the Axes. 

138 

139 pad : float, default: :rc:`axes.titlepad` 

140 The offset of the title from the top of the Axes, in points. 

141 

142 Returns 

143 ------- 

144 `.Text` 

145 The matplotlib text instance representing the title 

146 

147 Other Parameters 

148 ---------------- 

149 **kwargs : `.Text` properties 

150 Other keyword arguments are text properties, see `.Text` for a list 

151 of valid text properties. 

152 """ 

153 if loc is None: 

154 loc = mpl.rcParams['axes.titlelocation'] 

155 

156 if y is None: 

157 y = mpl.rcParams['axes.titley'] 

158 if y is None: 

159 y = 1.0 

160 else: 

161 self._autotitlepos = False 

162 kwargs['y'] = y 

163 

164 titles = {'left': self._left_title, 

165 'center': self.title, 

166 'right': self._right_title} 

167 title = _api.check_getitem(titles, loc=loc.lower()) 

168 default = { 

169 'fontsize': mpl.rcParams['axes.titlesize'], 

170 'fontweight': mpl.rcParams['axes.titleweight'], 

171 'verticalalignment': 'baseline', 

172 'horizontalalignment': loc.lower()} 

173 titlecolor = mpl.rcParams['axes.titlecolor'] 

174 if not cbook._str_lower_equal(titlecolor, 'auto'): 

175 default["color"] = titlecolor 

176 if pad is None: 

177 pad = mpl.rcParams['axes.titlepad'] 

178 self._set_title_offset_trans(float(pad)) 

179 title.set_text(label) 

180 title.update(default) 

181 if fontdict is not None: 181 ↛ 182line 181 didn't jump to line 182, because the condition on line 181 was never true

182 title.update(fontdict) 

183 title._internal_update(kwargs) 

184 return title 

185 

186 def get_legend_handles_labels(self, legend_handler_map=None): 

187 """ 

188 Return handles and labels for legend 

189 

190 ``ax.legend()`` is equivalent to :: 

191 

192 h, l = ax.get_legend_handles_labels() 

193 ax.legend(h, l) 

194 """ 

195 # pass through to legend. 

196 handles, labels = mlegend._get_legend_handles_labels( 

197 [self], legend_handler_map) 

198 return handles, labels 

199 

200 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

201 def legend(self, *args, **kwargs): 

202 """ 

203 Place a legend on the Axes. 

204 

205 Call signatures:: 

206 

207 legend() 

208 legend(handles, labels) 

209 legend(handles=handles) 

210 legend(labels) 

211 

212 The call signatures correspond to the following different ways to use 

213 this method: 

214 

215 **1. Automatic detection of elements to be shown in the legend** 

216 

217 The elements to be added to the legend are automatically determined, 

218 when you do not pass in any extra arguments. 

219 

220 In this case, the labels are taken from the artist. You can specify 

221 them either at artist creation or by calling the 

222 :meth:`~.Artist.set_label` method on the artist:: 

223 

224 ax.plot([1, 2, 3], label='Inline label') 

225 ax.legend() 

226 

227 or:: 

228 

229 line, = ax.plot([1, 2, 3]) 

230 line.set_label('Label via method') 

231 ax.legend() 

232 

233 .. note:: 

234 Specific artists can be excluded from the automatic legend element 

235 selection by using a label starting with an underscore, "_". 

236 A string starting with an underscore is the default label for all 

237 artists, so calling `.Axes.legend` without any arguments and 

238 without setting the labels manually will result in no legend being 

239 drawn. 

240 

241 

242 **2. Explicitly listing the artists and labels in the legend** 

243 

244 For full control of which artists have a legend entry, it is possible 

245 to pass an iterable of legend artists followed by an iterable of 

246 legend labels respectively:: 

247 

248 ax.legend([line1, line2, line3], ['label1', 'label2', 'label3']) 

249 

250 

251 **3. Explicitly listing the artists in the legend** 

252 

253 This is similar to 2, but the labels are taken from the artists' 

254 label properties. Example:: 

255 

256 line1, = ax.plot([1, 2, 3], label='label1') 

257 line2, = ax.plot([1, 2, 3], label='label2') 

258 ax.legend(handles=[line1, line2]) 

259 

260 

261 **4. Labeling existing plot elements** 

262 

263 .. admonition:: Discouraged 

264 

265 This call signature is discouraged, because the relation between 

266 plot elements and labels is only implicit by their order and can 

267 easily be mixed up. 

268 

269 To make a legend for all artists on an Axes, call this function with 

270 an iterable of strings, one for each legend item. For example:: 

271 

272 ax.plot([1, 2, 3]) 

273 ax.plot([5, 6, 7]) 

274 ax.legend(['First line', 'Second line']) 

275 

276 

277 Parameters 

278 ---------- 

279 handles : sequence of `.Artist`, optional 

280 A list of Artists (lines, patches) to be added to the legend. 

281 Use this together with *labels*, if you need full control on what 

282 is shown in the legend and the automatic mechanism described above 

283 is not sufficient. 

284 

285 The length of handles and labels should be the same in this 

286 case. If they are not, they are truncated to the smaller length. 

287 

288 labels : list of str, optional 

289 A list of labels to show next to the artists. 

290 Use this together with *handles*, if you need full control on what 

291 is shown in the legend and the automatic mechanism described above 

292 is not sufficient. 

293 

294 Returns 

295 ------- 

296 `~matplotlib.legend.Legend` 

297 

298 Other Parameters 

299 ---------------- 

300 %(_legend_kw_axes)s 

301 

302 See Also 

303 -------- 

304 .Figure.legend 

305 

306 Notes 

307 ----- 

308 Some artists are not supported by this function. See 

309 :doc:`/tutorials/intermediate/legend_guide` for details. 

310 

311 Examples 

312 -------- 

313 .. plot:: gallery/text_labels_and_annotations/legend.py 

314 """ 

315 handles, labels, extra_args, kwargs = mlegend._parse_legend_args( 

316 [self], 

317 *args, 

318 **kwargs) 

319 if len(extra_args): 319 ↛ 320line 319 didn't jump to line 320, because the condition on line 319 was never true

320 raise TypeError('legend only accepts two non-keyword arguments') 

321 self.legend_ = mlegend.Legend(self, handles, labels, **kwargs) 

322 self.legend_._remove_method = self._remove_legend 

323 return self.legend_ 

324 

325 def _remove_legend(self, legend): 

326 self.legend_ = None 

327 

328 def inset_axes(self, bounds, *, transform=None, zorder=5, **kwargs): 

329 """ 

330 Add a child inset Axes to this existing Axes. 

331 

332 Warnings 

333 -------- 

334 This method is experimental as of 3.0, and the API may change. 

335 

336 Parameters 

337 ---------- 

338 bounds : [x0, y0, width, height] 

339 Lower-left corner of inset Axes, and its width and height. 

340 

341 transform : `.Transform` 

342 Defaults to `ax.transAxes`, i.e. the units of *rect* are in 

343 Axes-relative coordinates. 

344 

345 projection : {None, 'aitoff', 'hammer', 'lambert', 'mollweide', \ 

346'polar', 'rectilinear', str}, optional 

347 The projection type of the inset `~.axes.Axes`. *str* is the name 

348 of a custom projection, see `~matplotlib.projections`. The default 

349 None results in a 'rectilinear' projection. 

350 

351 polar : bool, default: False 

352 If True, equivalent to projection='polar'. 

353 

354 axes_class : subclass type of `~.axes.Axes`, optional 

355 The `.axes.Axes` subclass that is instantiated. This parameter 

356 is incompatible with *projection* and *polar*. See 

357 :ref:`axisartist_users-guide-index` for examples. 

358 

359 zorder : number 

360 Defaults to 5 (same as `.Axes.legend`). Adjust higher or lower 

361 to change whether it is above or below data plotted on the 

362 parent Axes. 

363 

364 **kwargs 

365 Other keyword arguments are passed on to the inset Axes class. 

366 

367 Returns 

368 ------- 

369 ax 

370 The created `~.axes.Axes` instance. 

371 

372 Examples 

373 -------- 

374 This example makes two inset Axes, the first is in Axes-relative 

375 coordinates, and the second in data-coordinates:: 

376 

377 fig, ax = plt.subplots() 

378 ax.plot(range(10)) 

379 axin1 = ax.inset_axes([0.8, 0.1, 0.15, 0.15]) 

380 axin2 = ax.inset_axes( 

381 [5, 7, 2.3, 2.3], transform=ax.transData) 

382 

383 """ 

384 if transform is None: 384 ↛ 386line 384 didn't jump to line 386, because the condition on line 384 was never false

385 transform = self.transAxes 

386 kwargs.setdefault('label', 'inset_axes') 

387 

388 # This puts the rectangle into figure-relative coordinates. 

389 inset_locator = _TransformedBoundsLocator(bounds, transform) 

390 bounds = inset_locator(self, None).bounds 

391 projection_class, pkw = self.figure._process_projection_requirements( 

392 bounds, **kwargs) 

393 inset_ax = projection_class(self.figure, bounds, zorder=zorder, **pkw) 

394 

395 # this locator lets the axes move if in data coordinates. 

396 # it gets called in `ax.apply_aspect() (of all places) 

397 inset_ax.set_axes_locator(inset_locator) 

398 

399 self.add_child_axes(inset_ax) 

400 

401 return inset_ax 

402 

403 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

404 def indicate_inset(self, bounds, inset_ax=None, *, transform=None, 

405 facecolor='none', edgecolor='0.5', alpha=0.5, 

406 zorder=4.99, **kwargs): 

407 """ 

408 Add an inset indicator to the Axes. This is a rectangle on the plot 

409 at the position indicated by *bounds* that optionally has lines that 

410 connect the rectangle to an inset Axes (`.Axes.inset_axes`). 

411 

412 Warnings 

413 -------- 

414 This method is experimental as of 3.0, and the API may change. 

415 

416 Parameters 

417 ---------- 

418 bounds : [x0, y0, width, height] 

419 Lower-left corner of rectangle to be marked, and its width 

420 and height. 

421 

422 inset_ax : `.Axes` 

423 An optional inset Axes to draw connecting lines to. Two lines are 

424 drawn connecting the indicator box to the inset Axes on corners 

425 chosen so as to not overlap with the indicator box. 

426 

427 transform : `.Transform` 

428 Transform for the rectangle coordinates. Defaults to 

429 `ax.transAxes`, i.e. the units of *rect* are in Axes-relative 

430 coordinates. 

431 

432 facecolor : color, default: 'none' 

433 Facecolor of the rectangle. 

434 

435 edgecolor : color, default: '0.5' 

436 Color of the rectangle and color of the connecting lines. 

437 

438 alpha : float, default: 0.5 

439 Transparency of the rectangle and connector lines. 

440 

441 zorder : float, default: 4.99 

442 Drawing order of the rectangle and connector lines. The default, 

443 4.99, is just below the default level of inset Axes. 

444 

445 **kwargs 

446 Other keyword arguments are passed on to the `.Rectangle` patch: 

447 

448 %(Rectangle:kwdoc)s 

449 

450 Returns 

451 ------- 

452 rectangle_patch : `.patches.Rectangle` 

453 The indicator frame. 

454 

455 connector_lines : 4-tuple of `.patches.ConnectionPatch` 

456 The four connector lines connecting to (lower_left, upper_left, 

457 lower_right upper_right) corners of *inset_ax*. Two lines are 

458 set with visibility to *False*, but the user can set the 

459 visibility to True if the automatic choice is not deemed correct. 

460 

461 """ 

462 # to make the axes connectors work, we need to apply the aspect to 

463 # the parent axes. 

464 self.apply_aspect() 

465 

466 if transform is None: 466 ↛ 468line 466 didn't jump to line 468, because the condition on line 466 was never false

467 transform = self.transData 

468 kwargs.setdefault('label', '_indicate_inset') 

469 

470 x, y, width, height = bounds 

471 rectangle_patch = mpatches.Rectangle( 

472 (x, y), width, height, 

473 facecolor=facecolor, edgecolor=edgecolor, alpha=alpha, 

474 zorder=zorder, transform=transform, **kwargs) 

475 self.add_patch(rectangle_patch) 

476 

477 connects = [] 

478 

479 if inset_ax is not None: 

480 # connect the inset_axes to the rectangle 

481 for xy_inset_ax in [(0, 0), (0, 1), (1, 0), (1, 1)]: 

482 # inset_ax positions are in axes coordinates 

483 # The 0, 1 values define the four edges if the inset_ax 

484 # lower_left, upper_left, lower_right upper_right. 

485 ex, ey = xy_inset_ax 

486 if self.xaxis.get_inverted(): 

487 ex = 1 - ex 

488 if self.yaxis.get_inverted(): 

489 ey = 1 - ey 

490 xy_data = x + ex * width, y + ey * height 

491 p = mpatches.ConnectionPatch( 

492 xyA=xy_inset_ax, coordsA=inset_ax.transAxes, 

493 xyB=xy_data, coordsB=self.transData, 

494 arrowstyle="-", zorder=zorder, 

495 edgecolor=edgecolor, alpha=alpha) 

496 connects.append(p) 

497 self.add_patch(p) 

498 

499 # decide which two of the lines to keep visible.... 

500 pos = inset_ax.get_position() 

501 bboxins = pos.transformed(self.figure.transSubfigure) 

502 rectbbox = mtransforms.Bbox.from_bounds( 

503 *bounds 

504 ).transformed(transform) 

505 x0 = rectbbox.x0 < bboxins.x0 

506 x1 = rectbbox.x1 < bboxins.x1 

507 y0 = rectbbox.y0 < bboxins.y0 

508 y1 = rectbbox.y1 < bboxins.y1 

509 connects[0].set_visible(x0 ^ y0) 

510 connects[1].set_visible(x0 == y1) 

511 connects[2].set_visible(x1 == y0) 

512 connects[3].set_visible(x1 ^ y1) 

513 

514 return rectangle_patch, tuple(connects) if connects else None 

515 

516 def indicate_inset_zoom(self, inset_ax, **kwargs): 

517 """ 

518 Add an inset indicator rectangle to the Axes based on the axis 

519 limits for an *inset_ax* and draw connectors between *inset_ax* 

520 and the rectangle. 

521 

522 Warnings 

523 -------- 

524 This method is experimental as of 3.0, and the API may change. 

525 

526 Parameters 

527 ---------- 

528 inset_ax : `.Axes` 

529 Inset Axes to draw connecting lines to. Two lines are 

530 drawn connecting the indicator box to the inset Axes on corners 

531 chosen so as to not overlap with the indicator box. 

532 

533 **kwargs 

534 Other keyword arguments are passed on to `.Axes.indicate_inset` 

535 

536 Returns 

537 ------- 

538 rectangle_patch : `.patches.Rectangle` 

539 Rectangle artist. 

540 

541 connector_lines : 4-tuple of `.patches.ConnectionPatch` 

542 Each of four connector lines coming from the rectangle drawn on 

543 this axis, in the order lower left, upper left, lower right, 

544 upper right. 

545 Two are set with visibility to *False*, but the user can 

546 set the visibility to *True* if the automatic choice is not deemed 

547 correct. 

548 """ 

549 

550 xlim = inset_ax.get_xlim() 

551 ylim = inset_ax.get_ylim() 

552 rect = (xlim[0], ylim[0], xlim[1] - xlim[0], ylim[1] - ylim[0]) 

553 return self.indicate_inset(rect, inset_ax, **kwargs) 

554 

555 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

556 def secondary_xaxis(self, location, *, functions=None, **kwargs): 

557 """ 

558 Add a second x-axis to this `~.axes.Axes`. 

559 

560 For example if we want to have a second scale for the data plotted on 

561 the xaxis. 

562 

563 %(_secax_docstring)s 

564 

565 Examples 

566 -------- 

567 The main axis shows frequency, and the secondary axis shows period. 

568 

569 .. plot:: 

570 

571 fig, ax = plt.subplots() 

572 ax.loglog(range(1, 360, 5), range(1, 360, 5)) 

573 ax.set_xlabel('frequency [Hz]') 

574 

575 def invert(x): 

576 # 1/x with special treatment of x == 0 

577 x = np.array(x).astype(float) 

578 near_zero = np.isclose(x, 0) 

579 x[near_zero] = np.inf 

580 x[~near_zero] = 1 / x[~near_zero] 

581 return x 

582 

583 # the inverse of 1/x is itself 

584 secax = ax.secondary_xaxis('top', functions=(invert, invert)) 

585 secax.set_xlabel('Period [s]') 

586 plt.show() 

587 """ 

588 if location in ['top', 'bottom'] or isinstance(location, Real): 

589 secondary_ax = SecondaryAxis(self, 'x', location, functions, 

590 **kwargs) 

591 self.add_child_axes(secondary_ax) 

592 return secondary_ax 

593 else: 

594 raise ValueError('secondary_xaxis location must be either ' 

595 'a float or "top"/"bottom"') 

596 

597 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

598 def secondary_yaxis(self, location, *, functions=None, **kwargs): 

599 """ 

600 Add a second y-axis to this `~.axes.Axes`. 

601 

602 For example if we want to have a second scale for the data plotted on 

603 the yaxis. 

604 

605 %(_secax_docstring)s 

606 

607 Examples 

608 -------- 

609 Add a secondary Axes that converts from radians to degrees 

610 

611 .. plot:: 

612 

613 fig, ax = plt.subplots() 

614 ax.plot(range(1, 360, 5), range(1, 360, 5)) 

615 ax.set_ylabel('degrees') 

616 secax = ax.secondary_yaxis('right', functions=(np.deg2rad, 

617 np.rad2deg)) 

618 secax.set_ylabel('radians') 

619 """ 

620 if location in ['left', 'right'] or isinstance(location, Real): 

621 secondary_ax = SecondaryAxis(self, 'y', location, 

622 functions, **kwargs) 

623 self.add_child_axes(secondary_ax) 

624 return secondary_ax 

625 else: 

626 raise ValueError('secondary_yaxis location must be either ' 

627 'a float or "left"/"right"') 

628 

629 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

630 def text(self, x, y, s, fontdict=None, **kwargs): 

631 """ 

632 Add text to the Axes. 

633 

634 Add the text *s* to the Axes at location *x*, *y* in data coordinates. 

635 

636 Parameters 

637 ---------- 

638 x, y : float 

639 The position to place the text. By default, this is in data 

640 coordinates. The coordinate system can be changed using the 

641 *transform* parameter. 

642 

643 s : str 

644 The text. 

645 

646 fontdict : dict, default: None 

647 A dictionary to override the default text properties. If fontdict 

648 is None, the defaults are determined by `.rcParams`. 

649 

650 Returns 

651 ------- 

652 `.Text` 

653 The created `.Text` instance. 

654 

655 Other Parameters 

656 ---------------- 

657 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.text.Text` properties. 

658 Other miscellaneous text parameters. 

659 

660 %(Text:kwdoc)s 

661 

662 Examples 

663 -------- 

664 Individual keyword arguments can be used to override any given 

665 parameter:: 

666 

667 >>> text(x, y, s, fontsize=12) 

668 

669 The default transform specifies that text is in data coords, 

670 alternatively, you can specify text in axis coords ((0, 0) is 

671 lower-left and (1, 1) is upper-right). The example below places 

672 text in the center of the Axes:: 

673 

674 >>> text(0.5, 0.5, 'matplotlib', horizontalalignment='center', 

675 ... verticalalignment='center', transform=ax.transAxes) 

676 

677 You can put a rectangular box around the text instance (e.g., to 

678 set a background color) by using the keyword *bbox*. *bbox* is 

679 a dictionary of `~matplotlib.patches.Rectangle` 

680 properties. For example:: 

681 

682 >>> text(x, y, s, bbox=dict(facecolor='red', alpha=0.5)) 

683 """ 

684 effective_kwargs = { 

685 'verticalalignment': 'baseline', 

686 'horizontalalignment': 'left', 

687 'transform': self.transData, 

688 'clip_on': False, 

689 **(fontdict if fontdict is not None else {}), 

690 **kwargs, 

691 } 

692 t = mtext.Text(x, y, text=s, **effective_kwargs) 

693 t.set_clip_path(self.patch) 

694 self._add_text(t) 

695 return t 

696 

697 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

698 def annotate(self, text, xy, xytext=None, xycoords='data', textcoords=None, 

699 arrowprops=None, annotation_clip=None, **kwargs): 

700 # Signature must match Annotation. This is verified in 

701 # test_annotate_signature(). 

702 a = mtext.Annotation(text, xy, xytext=xytext, xycoords=xycoords, 

703 textcoords=textcoords, arrowprops=arrowprops, 

704 annotation_clip=annotation_clip, **kwargs) 

705 a.set_transform(mtransforms.IdentityTransform()) 

706 if 'clip_on' in kwargs: 

707 a.set_clip_path(self.patch) 

708 self._add_text(a) 

709 return a 

710 annotate.__doc__ = mtext.Annotation.__init__.__doc__ 

711 #### Lines and spans 

712 

713 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

714 def axhline(self, y=0, xmin=0, xmax=1, **kwargs): 

715 """ 

716 Add a horizontal line across the Axes. 

717 

718 Parameters 

719 ---------- 

720 y : float, default: 0 

721 y position in data coordinates of the horizontal line. 

722 

723 xmin : float, default: 0 

724 Should be between 0 and 1, 0 being the far left of the plot, 1 the 

725 far right of the plot. 

726 

727 xmax : float, default: 1 

728 Should be between 0 and 1, 0 being the far left of the plot, 1 the 

729 far right of the plot. 

730 

731 Returns 

732 ------- 

733 `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` 

734 

735 Other Parameters 

736 ---------------- 

737 **kwargs 

738 Valid keyword arguments are `.Line2D` properties, except for 

739 'transform': 

740 

741 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s 

742 

743 See Also 

744 -------- 

745 hlines : Add horizontal lines in data coordinates. 

746 axhspan : Add a horizontal span (rectangle) across the axis. 

747 axline : Add a line with an arbitrary slope. 

748 

749 Examples 

750 -------- 

751 * draw a thick red hline at 'y' = 0 that spans the xrange:: 

752 

753 >>> axhline(linewidth=4, color='r') 

754 

755 * draw a default hline at 'y' = 1 that spans the xrange:: 

756 

757 >>> axhline(y=1) 

758 

759 * draw a default hline at 'y' = .5 that spans the middle half of 

760 the xrange:: 

761 

762 >>> axhline(y=.5, xmin=0.25, xmax=0.75) 

763 """ 

764 self._check_no_units([xmin, xmax], ['xmin', 'xmax']) 

765 if "transform" in kwargs: 765 ↛ 766line 765 didn't jump to line 766, because the condition on line 765 was never true

766 raise ValueError("'transform' is not allowed as a keyword " 

767 "argument; axhline generates its own transform.") 

768 ymin, ymax = self.get_ybound() 

769 

770 # Strip away the units for comparison with non-unitized bounds. 

771 yy, = self._process_unit_info([("y", y)], kwargs) 

772 scaley = (yy < ymin) or (yy > ymax) 

773 

774 trans = self.get_yaxis_transform(which='grid') 

775 l = mlines.Line2D([xmin, xmax], [y, y], transform=trans, **kwargs) 

776 self.add_line(l) 

777 if scaley: 

778 self._request_autoscale_view("y") 

779 return l 

780 

781 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

782 def axvline(self, x=0, ymin=0, ymax=1, **kwargs): 

783 """ 

784 Add a vertical line across the Axes. 

785 

786 Parameters 

787 ---------- 

788 x : float, default: 0 

789 x position in data coordinates of the vertical line. 

790 

791 ymin : float, default: 0 

792 Should be between 0 and 1, 0 being the bottom of the plot, 1 the 

793 top of the plot. 

794 

795 ymax : float, default: 1 

796 Should be between 0 and 1, 0 being the bottom of the plot, 1 the 

797 top of the plot. 

798 

799 Returns 

800 ------- 

801 `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` 

802 

803 Other Parameters 

804 ---------------- 

805 **kwargs 

806 Valid keyword arguments are `.Line2D` properties, except for 

807 'transform': 

808 

809 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s 

810 

811 See Also 

812 -------- 

813 vlines : Add vertical lines in data coordinates. 

814 axvspan : Add a vertical span (rectangle) across the axis. 

815 axline : Add a line with an arbitrary slope. 

816 

817 Examples 

818 -------- 

819 * draw a thick red vline at *x* = 0 that spans the yrange:: 

820 

821 >>> axvline(linewidth=4, color='r') 

822 

823 * draw a default vline at *x* = 1 that spans the yrange:: 

824 

825 >>> axvline(x=1) 

826 

827 * draw a default vline at *x* = .5 that spans the middle half of 

828 the yrange:: 

829 

830 >>> axvline(x=.5, ymin=0.25, ymax=0.75) 

831 """ 

832 self._check_no_units([ymin, ymax], ['ymin', 'ymax']) 

833 if "transform" in kwargs: 833 ↛ 834line 833 didn't jump to line 834, because the condition on line 833 was never true

834 raise ValueError("'transform' is not allowed as a keyword " 

835 "argument; axvline generates its own transform.") 

836 xmin, xmax = self.get_xbound() 

837 

838 # Strip away the units for comparison with non-unitized bounds. 

839 xx, = self._process_unit_info([("x", x)], kwargs) 

840 scalex = (xx < xmin) or (xx > xmax) 

841 

842 trans = self.get_xaxis_transform(which='grid') 

843 l = mlines.Line2D([x, x], [ymin, ymax], transform=trans, **kwargs) 

844 self.add_line(l) 

845 if scalex: 

846 self._request_autoscale_view("x") 

847 return l 

848 

849 @staticmethod 

850 def _check_no_units(vals, names): 

851 # Helper method to check that vals are not unitized 

852 for val, name in zip(vals, names): 

853 if not munits._is_natively_supported(val): 

854 raise ValueError(f"{name} must be a single scalar value, " 

855 f"but got {val}") 

856 

857 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

858 def axline(self, xy1, xy2=None, *, slope=None, **kwargs): 

859 """ 

860 Add an infinitely long straight line. 

861 

862 The line can be defined either by two points *xy1* and *xy2*, or 

863 by one point *xy1* and a *slope*. 

864 

865 This draws a straight line "on the screen", regardless of the x and y 

866 scales, and is thus also suitable for drawing exponential decays in 

867 semilog plots, power laws in loglog plots, etc. However, *slope* 

868 should only be used with linear scales; It has no clear meaning for 

869 all other scales, and thus the behavior is undefined. Please specify 

870 the line using the points *xy1*, *xy2* for non-linear scales. 

871 

872 The *transform* keyword argument only applies to the points *xy1*, 

873 *xy2*. The *slope* (if given) is always in data coordinates. This can 

874 be used e.g. with ``ax.transAxes`` for drawing grid lines with a fixed 

875 slope. 

876 

877 Parameters 

878 ---------- 

879 xy1, xy2 : (float, float) 

880 Points for the line to pass through. 

881 Either *xy2* or *slope* has to be given. 

882 slope : float, optional 

883 The slope of the line. Either *xy2* or *slope* has to be given. 

884 

885 Returns 

886 ------- 

887 `.Line2D` 

888 

889 Other Parameters 

890 ---------------- 

891 **kwargs 

892 Valid kwargs are `.Line2D` properties 

893 

894 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s 

895 

896 See Also 

897 -------- 

898 axhline : for horizontal lines 

899 axvline : for vertical lines 

900 

901 Examples 

902 -------- 

903 Draw a thick red line passing through (0, 0) and (1, 1):: 

904 

905 >>> axline((0, 0), (1, 1), linewidth=4, color='r') 

906 """ 

907 if slope is not None and (self.get_xscale() != 'linear' or 

908 self.get_yscale() != 'linear'): 

909 raise TypeError("'slope' cannot be used with non-linear scales") 

910 

911 datalim = [xy1] if xy2 is None else [xy1, xy2] 

912 if "transform" in kwargs: 

913 # if a transform is passed (i.e. line points not in data space), 

914 # data limits should not be adjusted. 

915 datalim = [] 

916 

917 line = mlines._AxLine(xy1, xy2, slope, **kwargs) 

918 # Like add_line, but correctly handling data limits. 

919 self._set_artist_props(line) 

920 if line.get_clip_path() is None: 920 ↛ 922line 920 didn't jump to line 922, because the condition on line 920 was never false

921 line.set_clip_path(self.patch) 

922 if not line.get_label(): 922 ↛ 924line 922 didn't jump to line 924, because the condition on line 922 was never false

923 line.set_label(f"_child{len(self._children)}") 

924 self._children.append(line) 

925 line._remove_method = self._children.remove 

926 self.update_datalim(datalim) 

927 

928 self._request_autoscale_view() 

929 return line 

930 

931 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

932 def axhspan(self, ymin, ymax, xmin=0, xmax=1, **kwargs): 

933 """ 

934 Add a horizontal span (rectangle) across the Axes. 

935 

936 The rectangle spans from *ymin* to *ymax* vertically, and, by default, 

937 the whole x-axis horizontally. The x-span can be set using *xmin* 

938 (default: 0) and *xmax* (default: 1) which are in axis units; e.g. 

939 ``xmin = 0.5`` always refers to the middle of the x-axis regardless of 

940 the limits set by `~.Axes.set_xlim`. 

941 

942 Parameters 

943 ---------- 

944 ymin : float 

945 Lower y-coordinate of the span, in data units. 

946 ymax : float 

947 Upper y-coordinate of the span, in data units. 

948 xmin : float, default: 0 

949 Lower x-coordinate of the span, in x-axis (0-1) units. 

950 xmax : float, default: 1 

951 Upper x-coordinate of the span, in x-axis (0-1) units. 

952 

953 Returns 

954 ------- 

955 `~matplotlib.patches.Polygon` 

956 Horizontal span (rectangle) from (xmin, ymin) to (xmax, ymax). 

957 

958 Other Parameters 

959 ---------------- 

960 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.patches.Polygon` properties 

961 

962 %(Polygon:kwdoc)s 

963 

964 See Also 

965 -------- 

966 axvspan : Add a vertical span across the Axes. 

967 """ 

968 # Strip units away. 

969 self._check_no_units([xmin, xmax], ['xmin', 'xmax']) 

970 (ymin, ymax), = self._process_unit_info([("y", [ymin, ymax])], kwargs) 

971 

972 verts = (xmin, ymin), (xmin, ymax), (xmax, ymax), (xmax, ymin) 

973 p = mpatches.Polygon(verts, **kwargs) 

974 p.set_transform(self.get_yaxis_transform(which="grid")) 

975 self.add_patch(p) 

976 self._request_autoscale_view("y") 

977 return p 

978 

979 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

980 def axvspan(self, xmin, xmax, ymin=0, ymax=1, **kwargs): 

981 """ 

982 Add a vertical span (rectangle) across the Axes. 

983 

984 The rectangle spans from *xmin* to *xmax* horizontally, and, by 

985 default, the whole y-axis vertically. The y-span can be set using 

986 *ymin* (default: 0) and *ymax* (default: 1) which are in axis units; 

987 e.g. ``ymin = 0.5`` always refers to the middle of the y-axis 

988 regardless of the limits set by `~.Axes.set_ylim`. 

989 

990 Parameters 

991 ---------- 

992 xmin : float 

993 Lower x-coordinate of the span, in data units. 

994 xmax : float 

995 Upper x-coordinate of the span, in data units. 

996 ymin : float, default: 0 

997 Lower y-coordinate of the span, in y-axis units (0-1). 

998 ymax : float, default: 1 

999 Upper y-coordinate of the span, in y-axis units (0-1). 

1000 

1001 Returns 

1002 ------- 

1003 `~matplotlib.patches.Polygon` 

1004 Vertical span (rectangle) from (xmin, ymin) to (xmax, ymax). 

1005 

1006 Other Parameters 

1007 ---------------- 

1008 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.patches.Polygon` properties 

1009 

1010 %(Polygon:kwdoc)s 

1011 

1012 See Also 

1013 -------- 

1014 axhspan : Add a horizontal span across the Axes. 

1015 

1016 Examples 

1017 -------- 

1018 Draw a vertical, green, translucent rectangle from x = 1.25 to 

1019 x = 1.55 that spans the yrange of the Axes. 

1020 

1021 >>> axvspan(1.25, 1.55, facecolor='g', alpha=0.5) 

1022 

1023 """ 

1024 # Strip units away. 

1025 self._check_no_units([ymin, ymax], ['ymin', 'ymax']) 

1026 (xmin, xmax), = self._process_unit_info([("x", [xmin, xmax])], kwargs) 

1027 

1028 verts = [(xmin, ymin), (xmin, ymax), (xmax, ymax), (xmax, ymin)] 

1029 p = mpatches.Polygon(verts, **kwargs) 

1030 p.set_transform(self.get_xaxis_transform(which="grid")) 

1031 p.get_path()._interpolation_steps = 100 

1032 self.add_patch(p) 

1033 self._request_autoscale_view("x") 

1034 return p 

1035 

1036 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["y", "xmin", "xmax", "colors"], 

1037 label_namer="y") 

1038 def hlines(self, y, xmin, xmax, colors=None, linestyles='solid', 

1039 label='', **kwargs): 

1040 """ 

1041 Plot horizontal lines at each *y* from *xmin* to *xmax*. 

1042 

1043 Parameters 

1044 ---------- 

1045 y : float or array-like 

1046 y-indexes where to plot the lines. 

1047 

1048 xmin, xmax : float or array-like 

1049 Respective beginning and end of each line. If scalars are 

1050 provided, all lines will have the same length. 

1051 

1052 colors : list of colors, default: :rc:`lines.color` 

1053 

1054 linestyles : {'solid', 'dashed', 'dashdot', 'dotted'}, optional 

1055 

1056 label : str, default: '' 

1057 

1058 Returns 

1059 ------- 

1060 `~matplotlib.collections.LineCollection` 

1061 

1062 Other Parameters 

1063 ---------------- 

1064 data : indexable object, optional 

1065 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

1066 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.collections.LineCollection` properties. 

1067 

1068 See Also 

1069 -------- 

1070 vlines : vertical lines 

1071 axhline : horizontal line across the Axes 

1072 """ 

1073 

1074 # We do the conversion first since not all unitized data is uniform 

1075 xmin, xmax, y = self._process_unit_info( 

1076 [("x", xmin), ("x", xmax), ("y", y)], kwargs) 

1077 

1078 if not np.iterable(y): 

1079 y = [y] 

1080 if not np.iterable(xmin): 

1081 xmin = [xmin] 

1082 if not np.iterable(xmax): 

1083 xmax = [xmax] 

1084 

1085 # Create and combine masked_arrays from input 

1086 y, xmin, xmax = cbook._combine_masks(y, xmin, xmax) 

1087 y = np.ravel(y) 

1088 xmin = np.ravel(xmin) 

1089 xmax = np.ravel(xmax) 

1090 

1091 masked_verts = np.ma.empty((len(y), 2, 2)) 

1092 masked_verts[:, 0, 0] = xmin 

1093 masked_verts[:, 0, 1] = y 

1094 masked_verts[:, 1, 0] = xmax 

1095 masked_verts[:, 1, 1] = y 

1096 

1097 lines = mcoll.LineCollection(masked_verts, colors=colors, 

1098 linestyles=linestyles, label=label) 

1099 self.add_collection(lines, autolim=False) 

1100 lines._internal_update(kwargs) 

1101 

1102 if len(y) > 0: 

1103 # Extreme values of xmin/xmax/y. Using masked_verts here handles 

1104 # the case of y being a masked *object* array (as can be generated 

1105 # e.g. by errorbar()), which would make nanmin/nanmax stumble. 

1106 minx = np.nanmin(masked_verts[..., 0]) 

1107 maxx = np.nanmax(masked_verts[..., 0]) 

1108 miny = np.nanmin(masked_verts[..., 1]) 

1109 maxy = np.nanmax(masked_verts[..., 1]) 

1110 corners = (minx, miny), (maxx, maxy) 

1111 self.update_datalim(corners) 

1112 self._request_autoscale_view() 

1113 

1114 return lines 

1115 

1116 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x", "ymin", "ymax", "colors"], 

1117 label_namer="x") 

1118 def vlines(self, x, ymin, ymax, colors=None, linestyles='solid', 

1119 label='', **kwargs): 

1120 """ 

1121 Plot vertical lines at each *x* from *ymin* to *ymax*. 

1122 

1123 Parameters 

1124 ---------- 

1125 x : float or array-like 

1126 x-indexes where to plot the lines. 

1127 

1128 ymin, ymax : float or array-like 

1129 Respective beginning and end of each line. If scalars are 

1130 provided, all lines will have the same length. 

1131 

1132 colors : list of colors, default: :rc:`lines.color` 

1133 

1134 linestyles : {'solid', 'dashed', 'dashdot', 'dotted'}, optional 

1135 

1136 label : str, default: '' 

1137 

1138 Returns 

1139 ------- 

1140 `~matplotlib.collections.LineCollection` 

1141 

1142 Other Parameters 

1143 ---------------- 

1144 data : indexable object, optional 

1145 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

1146 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.collections.LineCollection` properties. 

1147 

1148 See Also 

1149 -------- 

1150 hlines : horizontal lines 

1151 axvline : vertical line across the Axes 

1152 """ 

1153 

1154 # We do the conversion first since not all unitized data is uniform 

1155 x, ymin, ymax = self._process_unit_info( 

1156 [("x", x), ("y", ymin), ("y", ymax)], kwargs) 

1157 

1158 if not np.iterable(x): 

1159 x = [x] 

1160 if not np.iterable(ymin): 

1161 ymin = [ymin] 

1162 if not np.iterable(ymax): 

1163 ymax = [ymax] 

1164 

1165 # Create and combine masked_arrays from input 

1166 x, ymin, ymax = cbook._combine_masks(x, ymin, ymax) 

1167 x = np.ravel(x) 

1168 ymin = np.ravel(ymin) 

1169 ymax = np.ravel(ymax) 

1170 

1171 masked_verts = np.ma.empty((len(x), 2, 2)) 

1172 masked_verts[:, 0, 0] = x 

1173 masked_verts[:, 0, 1] = ymin 

1174 masked_verts[:, 1, 0] = x 

1175 masked_verts[:, 1, 1] = ymax 

1176 

1177 lines = mcoll.LineCollection(masked_verts, colors=colors, 

1178 linestyles=linestyles, label=label) 

1179 self.add_collection(lines, autolim=False) 

1180 lines._internal_update(kwargs) 

1181 

1182 if len(x) > 0: 

1183 # Extreme values of x/ymin/ymax. Using masked_verts here handles 

1184 # the case of x being a masked *object* array (as can be generated 

1185 # e.g. by errorbar()), which would make nanmin/nanmax stumble. 

1186 minx = np.nanmin(masked_verts[..., 0]) 

1187 maxx = np.nanmax(masked_verts[..., 0]) 

1188 miny = np.nanmin(masked_verts[..., 1]) 

1189 maxy = np.nanmax(masked_verts[..., 1]) 

1190 corners = (minx, miny), (maxx, maxy) 

1191 self.update_datalim(corners) 

1192 self._request_autoscale_view() 

1193 

1194 return lines 

1195 

1196 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["positions", "lineoffsets", 

1197 "linelengths", "linewidths", 

1198 "colors", "linestyles"]) 

1199 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

1200 def eventplot(self, positions, orientation='horizontal', lineoffsets=1, 

1201 linelengths=1, linewidths=None, colors=None, alpha=None, 

1202 linestyles='solid', **kwargs): 

1203 """ 

1204 Plot identical parallel lines at the given positions. 

1205 

1206 This type of plot is commonly used in neuroscience for representing 

1207 neural events, where it is usually called a spike raster, dot raster, 

1208 or raster plot. 

1209 

1210 However, it is useful in any situation where you wish to show the 

1211 timing or position of multiple sets of discrete events, such as the 

1212 arrival times of people to a business on each day of the month or the 

1213 date of hurricanes each year of the last century. 

1214 

1215 Parameters 

1216 ---------- 

1217 positions : array-like or list of array-like 

1218 A 1D array-like defines the positions of one sequence of events. 

1219 

1220 Multiple groups of events may be passed as a list of array-likes. 

1221 Each group can be styled independently by passing lists of values 

1222 to *lineoffsets*, *linelengths*, *linewidths*, *colors* and 

1223 *linestyles*. 

1224 

1225 Note that *positions* can be a 2D array, but in practice different 

1226 event groups usually have different counts so that one will use a 

1227 list of different-length arrays rather than a 2D array. 

1228 

1229 orientation : {'horizontal', 'vertical'}, default: 'horizontal' 

1230 The direction of the event sequence: 

1231 

1232 - 'horizontal': the events are arranged horizontally. 

1233 The indicator lines are vertical. 

1234 - 'vertical': the events are arranged vertically. 

1235 The indicator lines are horizontal. 

1236 

1237 lineoffsets : float or array-like, default: 1 

1238 The offset of the center of the lines from the origin, in the 

1239 direction orthogonal to *orientation*. 

1240 

1241 If *positions* is 2D, this can be a sequence with length matching 

1242 the length of *positions*. 

1243 

1244 linelengths : float or array-like, default: 1 

1245 The total height of the lines (i.e. the lines stretches from 

1246 ``lineoffset - linelength/2`` to ``lineoffset + linelength/2``). 

1247 

1248 If *positions* is 2D, this can be a sequence with length matching 

1249 the length of *positions*. 

1250 

1251 linewidths : float or array-like, default: :rc:`lines.linewidth` 

1252 The line width(s) of the event lines, in points. 

1253 

1254 If *positions* is 2D, this can be a sequence with length matching 

1255 the length of *positions*. 

1256 

1257 colors : color or list of colors, default: :rc:`lines.color` 

1258 The color(s) of the event lines. 

1259 

1260 If *positions* is 2D, this can be a sequence with length matching 

1261 the length of *positions*. 

1262 

1263 alpha : float or array-like, default: 1 

1264 The alpha blending value(s), between 0 (transparent) and 1 

1265 (opaque). 

1266 

1267 If *positions* is 2D, this can be a sequence with length matching 

1268 the length of *positions*. 

1269 

1270 linestyles : str or tuple or list of such values, default: 'solid' 

1271 Default is 'solid'. Valid strings are ['solid', 'dashed', 

1272 'dashdot', 'dotted', '-', '--', '-.', ':']. Dash tuples 

1273 should be of the form:: 

1274 

1275 (offset, onoffseq), 

1276 

1277 where *onoffseq* is an even length tuple of on and off ink 

1278 in points. 

1279 

1280 If *positions* is 2D, this can be a sequence with length matching 

1281 the length of *positions*. 

1282 

1283 data : indexable object, optional 

1284 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

1285 

1286 **kwargs 

1287 Other keyword arguments are line collection properties. See 

1288 `.LineCollection` for a list of the valid properties. 

1289 

1290 Returns 

1291 ------- 

1292 list of `.EventCollection` 

1293 The `.EventCollection` that were added. 

1294 

1295 Notes 

1296 ----- 

1297 For *linelengths*, *linewidths*, *colors*, *alpha* and *linestyles*, if 

1298 only a single value is given, that value is applied to all lines. If an 

1299 array-like is given, it must have the same length as *positions*, and 

1300 each value will be applied to the corresponding row of the array. 

1301 

1302 Examples 

1303 -------- 

1304 .. plot:: gallery/lines_bars_and_markers/eventplot_demo.py 

1305 """ 

1306 

1307 lineoffsets, linelengths = self._process_unit_info( 

1308 [("y", lineoffsets), ("y", linelengths)], kwargs) 

1309 

1310 # fix positions, noting that it can be a list of lists: 

1311 if not np.iterable(positions): 1311 ↛ 1312line 1311 didn't jump to line 1312, because the condition on line 1311 was never true

1312 positions = [positions] 

1313 elif any(np.iterable(position) for position in positions): 

1314 positions = [np.asanyarray(position) for position in positions] 

1315 else: 

1316 positions = [np.asanyarray(positions)] 

1317 

1318 if len(positions) == 0: 1318 ↛ 1319line 1318 didn't jump to line 1319, because the condition on line 1318 was never true

1319 return [] 

1320 

1321 poss = [] 

1322 for position in positions: 

1323 poss += self._process_unit_info([("x", position)], kwargs) 

1324 positions = poss 

1325 

1326 # prevent 'singular' keys from **kwargs dict from overriding the effect 

1327 # of 'plural' keyword arguments (e.g. 'color' overriding 'colors') 

1328 colors = cbook._local_over_kwdict(colors, kwargs, 'color') 

1329 linewidths = cbook._local_over_kwdict(linewidths, kwargs, 'linewidth') 

1330 linestyles = cbook._local_over_kwdict(linestyles, kwargs, 'linestyle') 

1331 

1332 if not np.iterable(lineoffsets): 

1333 lineoffsets = [lineoffsets] 

1334 if not np.iterable(linelengths): 

1335 linelengths = [linelengths] 

1336 if not np.iterable(linewidths): 

1337 linewidths = [linewidths] 

1338 if not np.iterable(colors): 

1339 colors = [colors] 

1340 if not np.iterable(alpha): 

1341 alpha = [alpha] 

1342 if hasattr(linestyles, 'lower') or not np.iterable(linestyles): 

1343 linestyles = [linestyles] 

1344 

1345 lineoffsets = np.asarray(lineoffsets) 

1346 linelengths = np.asarray(linelengths) 

1347 linewidths = np.asarray(linewidths) 

1348 

1349 if len(lineoffsets) == 0: 1349 ↛ 1350line 1349 didn't jump to line 1350, because the condition on line 1349 was never true

1350 lineoffsets = [None] 

1351 if len(linelengths) == 0: 1351 ↛ 1352line 1351 didn't jump to line 1352, because the condition on line 1351 was never true

1352 linelengths = [None] 

1353 if len(linewidths) == 0: 1353 ↛ 1354line 1353 didn't jump to line 1354, because the condition on line 1353 was never true

1354 lineoffsets = [None] 

1355 if len(linewidths) == 0: 1355 ↛ 1356line 1355 didn't jump to line 1356, because the condition on line 1355 was never true

1356 lineoffsets = [None] 

1357 if len(colors) == 0: 1357 ↛ 1358line 1357 didn't jump to line 1358, because the condition on line 1357 was never true

1358 colors = [None] 

1359 try: 

1360 # Early conversion of the colors into RGBA values to take care 

1361 # of cases like colors='0.5' or colors='C1'. (Issue #8193) 

1362 colors = mcolors.to_rgba_array(colors) 

1363 except ValueError: 

1364 # Will fail if any element of *colors* is None. But as long 

1365 # as len(colors) == 1 or len(positions), the rest of the 

1366 # code should process *colors* properly. 

1367 pass 

1368 

1369 if len(lineoffsets) == 1 and len(positions) != 1: 

1370 lineoffsets = np.tile(lineoffsets, len(positions)) 

1371 lineoffsets[0] = 0 

1372 lineoffsets = np.cumsum(lineoffsets) 

1373 if len(linelengths) == 1: 

1374 linelengths = np.tile(linelengths, len(positions)) 

1375 if len(linewidths) == 1: 

1376 linewidths = np.tile(linewidths, len(positions)) 

1377 if len(colors) == 1: 

1378 colors = list(colors) * len(positions) 

1379 if len(alpha) == 1: 

1380 alpha = list(alpha) * len(positions) 

1381 if len(linestyles) == 1: 

1382 linestyles = [linestyles] * len(positions) 

1383 

1384 if len(lineoffsets) != len(positions): 1384 ↛ 1385line 1384 didn't jump to line 1385, because the condition on line 1384 was never true

1385 raise ValueError('lineoffsets and positions are unequal sized ' 

1386 'sequences') 

1387 if len(linelengths) != len(positions): 1387 ↛ 1388line 1387 didn't jump to line 1388, because the condition on line 1387 was never true

1388 raise ValueError('linelengths and positions are unequal sized ' 

1389 'sequences') 

1390 if len(linewidths) != len(positions): 1390 ↛ 1391line 1390 didn't jump to line 1391, because the condition on line 1390 was never true

1391 raise ValueError('linewidths and positions are unequal sized ' 

1392 'sequences') 

1393 if len(colors) != len(positions): 1393 ↛ 1394line 1393 didn't jump to line 1394, because the condition on line 1393 was never true

1394 raise ValueError('colors and positions are unequal sized ' 

1395 'sequences') 

1396 if len(alpha) != len(positions): 

1397 raise ValueError('alpha and positions are unequal sized ' 

1398 'sequences') 

1399 if len(linestyles) != len(positions): 1399 ↛ 1400line 1399 didn't jump to line 1400, because the condition on line 1399 was never true

1400 raise ValueError('linestyles and positions are unequal sized ' 

1401 'sequences') 

1402 

1403 colls = [] 

1404 for position, lineoffset, linelength, linewidth, color, alpha_, \ 

1405 linestyle in \ 

1406 zip(positions, lineoffsets, linelengths, linewidths, 

1407 colors, alpha, linestyles): 

1408 coll = mcoll.EventCollection(position, 

1409 orientation=orientation, 

1410 lineoffset=lineoffset, 

1411 linelength=linelength, 

1412 linewidth=linewidth, 

1413 color=color, 

1414 alpha=alpha_, 

1415 linestyle=linestyle) 

1416 self.add_collection(coll, autolim=False) 

1417 coll._internal_update(kwargs) 

1418 colls.append(coll) 

1419 

1420 if len(positions) > 0: 1420 ↛ 1440line 1420 didn't jump to line 1440, because the condition on line 1420 was never false

1421 # try to get min/max 

1422 min_max = [(np.min(_p), np.max(_p)) for _p in positions 

1423 if len(_p) > 0] 

1424 # if we have any non-empty positions, try to autoscale 

1425 if len(min_max) > 0: 

1426 mins, maxes = zip(*min_max) 

1427 minpos = np.min(mins) 

1428 maxpos = np.max(maxes) 

1429 

1430 minline = (lineoffsets - linelengths).min() 

1431 maxline = (lineoffsets + linelengths).max() 

1432 

1433 if orientation == "vertical": 

1434 corners = (minline, minpos), (maxline, maxpos) 

1435 else: # "horizontal" 

1436 corners = (minpos, minline), (maxpos, maxline) 

1437 self.update_datalim(corners) 

1438 self._request_autoscale_view() 

1439 

1440 return colls 

1441 

1442 #### Basic plotting 

1443 

1444 # Uses a custom implementation of data-kwarg handling in 

1445 # _process_plot_var_args. 

1446 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

1447 def plot(self, *args, scalex=True, scaley=True, data=None, **kwargs): 

1448 """ 

1449 Plot y versus x as lines and/or markers. 

1450 

1451 Call signatures:: 

1452 

1453 plot([x], y, [fmt], *, data=None, **kwargs) 

1454 plot([x], y, [fmt], [x2], y2, [fmt2], ..., **kwargs) 

1455 

1456 The coordinates of the points or line nodes are given by *x*, *y*. 

1457 

1458 The optional parameter *fmt* is a convenient way for defining basic 

1459 formatting like color, marker and linestyle. It's a shortcut string 

1460 notation described in the *Notes* section below. 

1461 

1462 >>> plot(x, y) # plot x and y using default line style and color 

1463 >>> plot(x, y, 'bo') # plot x and y using blue circle markers 

1464 >>> plot(y) # plot y using x as index array 0..N-1 

1465 >>> plot(y, 'r+') # ditto, but with red plusses 

1466 

1467 You can use `.Line2D` properties as keyword arguments for more 

1468 control on the appearance. Line properties and *fmt* can be mixed. 

1469 The following two calls yield identical results: 

1470 

1471 >>> plot(x, y, 'go--', linewidth=2, markersize=12) 

1472 >>> plot(x, y, color='green', marker='o', linestyle='dashed', 

1473 ... linewidth=2, markersize=12) 

1474 

1475 When conflicting with *fmt*, keyword arguments take precedence. 

1476 

1477 

1478 **Plotting labelled data** 

1479 

1480 There's a convenient way for plotting objects with labelled data (i.e. 

1481 data that can be accessed by index ``obj['y']``). Instead of giving 

1482 the data in *x* and *y*, you can provide the object in the *data* 

1483 parameter and just give the labels for *x* and *y*:: 

1484 

1485 >>> plot('xlabel', 'ylabel', data=obj) 

1486 

1487 All indexable objects are supported. This could e.g. be a `dict`, a 

1488 `pandas.DataFrame` or a structured numpy array. 

1489 

1490 

1491 **Plotting multiple sets of data** 

1492 

1493 There are various ways to plot multiple sets of data. 

1494 

1495 - The most straight forward way is just to call `plot` multiple times. 

1496 Example: 

1497 

1498 >>> plot(x1, y1, 'bo') 

1499 >>> plot(x2, y2, 'go') 

1500 

1501 - If *x* and/or *y* are 2D arrays a separate data set will be drawn 

1502 for every column. If both *x* and *y* are 2D, they must have the 

1503 same shape. If only one of them is 2D with shape (N, m) the other 

1504 must have length N and will be used for every data set m. 

1505 

1506 Example: 

1507 

1508 >>> x = [1, 2, 3] 

1509 >>> y = np.array([[1, 2], [3, 4], [5, 6]]) 

1510 >>> plot(x, y) 

1511 

1512 is equivalent to: 

1513 

1514 >>> for col in range(y.shape[1]): 

1515 ... plot(x, y[:, col]) 

1516 

1517 - The third way is to specify multiple sets of *[x]*, *y*, *[fmt]* 

1518 groups:: 

1519 

1520 >>> plot(x1, y1, 'g^', x2, y2, 'g-') 

1521 

1522 In this case, any additional keyword argument applies to all 

1523 datasets. Also, this syntax cannot be combined with the *data* 

1524 parameter. 

1525 

1526 By default, each line is assigned a different style specified by a 

1527 'style cycle'. The *fmt* and line property parameters are only 

1528 necessary if you want explicit deviations from these defaults. 

1529 Alternatively, you can also change the style cycle using 

1530 :rc:`axes.prop_cycle`. 

1531 

1532 

1533 Parameters 

1534 ---------- 

1535 x, y : array-like or scalar 

1536 The horizontal / vertical coordinates of the data points. 

1537 *x* values are optional and default to ``range(len(y))``. 

1538 

1539 Commonly, these parameters are 1D arrays. 

1540 

1541 They can also be scalars, or two-dimensional (in that case, the 

1542 columns represent separate data sets). 

1543 

1544 These arguments cannot be passed as keywords. 

1545 

1546 fmt : str, optional 

1547 A format string, e.g. 'ro' for red circles. See the *Notes* 

1548 section for a full description of the format strings. 

1549 

1550 Format strings are just an abbreviation for quickly setting 

1551 basic line properties. All of these and more can also be 

1552 controlled by keyword arguments. 

1553 

1554 This argument cannot be passed as keyword. 

1555 

1556 data : indexable object, optional 

1557 An object with labelled data. If given, provide the label names to 

1558 plot in *x* and *y*. 

1559 

1560 .. note:: 

1561 Technically there's a slight ambiguity in calls where the 

1562 second label is a valid *fmt*. ``plot('n', 'o', data=obj)`` 

1563 could be ``plt(x, y)`` or ``plt(y, fmt)``. In such cases, 

1564 the former interpretation is chosen, but a warning is issued. 

1565 You may suppress the warning by adding an empty format string 

1566 ``plot('n', 'o', '', data=obj)``. 

1567 

1568 Returns 

1569 ------- 

1570 list of `.Line2D` 

1571 A list of lines representing the plotted data. 

1572 

1573 Other Parameters 

1574 ---------------- 

1575 scalex, scaley : bool, default: True 

1576 These parameters determine if the view limits are adapted to the 

1577 data limits. The values are passed on to 

1578 `~.axes.Axes.autoscale_view`. 

1579 

1580 **kwargs : `.Line2D` properties, optional 

1581 *kwargs* are used to specify properties like a line label (for 

1582 auto legends), linewidth, antialiasing, marker face color. 

1583 Example:: 

1584 

1585 >>> plot([1, 2, 3], [1, 2, 3], 'go-', label='line 1', linewidth=2) 

1586 >>> plot([1, 2, 3], [1, 4, 9], 'rs', label='line 2') 

1587 

1588 If you specify multiple lines with one plot call, the kwargs apply 

1589 to all those lines. In case the label object is iterable, each 

1590 element is used as labels for each set of data. 

1591 

1592 Here is a list of available `.Line2D` properties: 

1593 

1594 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s 

1595 

1596 See Also 

1597 -------- 

1598 scatter : XY scatter plot with markers of varying size and/or color ( 

1599 sometimes also called bubble chart). 

1600 

1601 Notes 

1602 ----- 

1603 **Format Strings** 

1604 

1605 A format string consists of a part for color, marker and line:: 

1606 

1607 fmt = '[marker][line][color]' 

1608 

1609 Each of them is optional. If not provided, the value from the style 

1610 cycle is used. Exception: If ``line`` is given, but no ``marker``, 

1611 the data will be a line without markers. 

1612 

1613 Other combinations such as ``[color][marker][line]`` are also 

1614 supported, but note that their parsing may be ambiguous. 

1615 

1616 **Markers** 

1617 

1618 ============= =============================== 

1619 character description 

1620 ============= =============================== 

1621 ``'.'`` point marker 

1622 ``','`` pixel marker 

1623 ``'o'`` circle marker 

1624 ``'v'`` triangle_down marker 

1625 ``'^'`` triangle_up marker 

1626 ``'<'`` triangle_left marker 

1627 ``'>'`` triangle_right marker 

1628 ``'1'`` tri_down marker 

1629 ``'2'`` tri_up marker 

1630 ``'3'`` tri_left marker 

1631 ``'4'`` tri_right marker 

1632 ``'8'`` octagon marker 

1633 ``'s'`` square marker 

1634 ``'p'`` pentagon marker 

1635 ``'P'`` plus (filled) marker 

1636 ``'*'`` star marker 

1637 ``'h'`` hexagon1 marker 

1638 ``'H'`` hexagon2 marker 

1639 ``'+'`` plus marker 

1640 ``'x'`` x marker 

1641 ``'X'`` x (filled) marker 

1642 ``'D'`` diamond marker 

1643 ``'d'`` thin_diamond marker 

1644 ``'|'`` vline marker 

1645 ``'_'`` hline marker 

1646 ============= =============================== 

1647 

1648 **Line Styles** 

1649 

1650 ============= =============================== 

1651 character description 

1652 ============= =============================== 

1653 ``'-'`` solid line style 

1654 ``'--'`` dashed line style 

1655 ``'-.'`` dash-dot line style 

1656 ``':'`` dotted line style 

1657 ============= =============================== 

1658 

1659 Example format strings:: 

1660 

1661 'b' # blue markers with default shape 

1662 'or' # red circles 

1663 '-g' # green solid line 

1664 '--' # dashed line with default color 

1665 '^k:' # black triangle_up markers connected by a dotted line 

1666 

1667 **Colors** 

1668 

1669 The supported color abbreviations are the single letter codes 

1670 

1671 ============= =============================== 

1672 character color 

1673 ============= =============================== 

1674 ``'b'`` blue 

1675 ``'g'`` green 

1676 ``'r'`` red 

1677 ``'c'`` cyan 

1678 ``'m'`` magenta 

1679 ``'y'`` yellow 

1680 ``'k'`` black 

1681 ``'w'`` white 

1682 ============= =============================== 

1683 

1684 and the ``'CN'`` colors that index into the default property cycle. 

1685 

1686 If the color is the only part of the format string, you can 

1687 additionally use any `matplotlib.colors` spec, e.g. full names 

1688 (``'green'``) or hex strings (``'#008000'``). 

1689 """ 

1690 kwargs = cbook.normalize_kwargs(kwargs, mlines.Line2D) 

1691 lines = [*self._get_lines(*args, data=data, **kwargs)] 

1692 for line in lines: 

1693 self.add_line(line) 

1694 if scalex: 1694 ↛ 1696line 1694 didn't jump to line 1696, because the condition on line 1694 was never false

1695 self._request_autoscale_view("x") 

1696 if scaley: 1696 ↛ 1698line 1696 didn't jump to line 1698, because the condition on line 1696 was never false

1697 self._request_autoscale_view("y") 

1698 return lines 

1699 

1700 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x", "y"], label_namer="y") 

1701 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

1702 def plot_date(self, x, y, fmt='o', tz=None, xdate=True, ydate=False, 

1703 **kwargs): 

1704 """ 

1705 [*Discouraged*] Plot coercing the axis to treat floats as dates. 

1706 

1707 .. admonition:: Discouraged 

1708 

1709 This method exists for historic reasons and will be deprecated in 

1710 the future. 

1711 

1712 - ``datetime``-like data should directly be plotted using 

1713 `~.Axes.plot`. 

1714 - If you need to plot plain numeric data as :ref:`date-format` or 

1715 need to set a timezone, call ``ax.xaxis.axis_date`` / 

1716 ``ax.yaxis.axis_date`` before `~.Axes.plot`. See 

1717 `.Axis.axis_date`. 

1718 

1719 Similar to `.plot`, this plots *y* vs. *x* as lines or markers. 

1720 However, the axis labels are formatted as dates depending on *xdate* 

1721 and *ydate*. Note that `.plot` will work with `datetime` and 

1722 `numpy.datetime64` objects without resorting to this method. 

1723 

1724 Parameters 

1725 ---------- 

1726 x, y : array-like 

1727 The coordinates of the data points. If *xdate* or *ydate* is 

1728 *True*, the respective values *x* or *y* are interpreted as 

1729 :ref:`Matplotlib dates <date-format>`. 

1730 

1731 fmt : str, optional 

1732 The plot format string. For details, see the corresponding 

1733 parameter in `.plot`. 

1734 

1735 tz : timezone string or `datetime.tzinfo`, default: :rc:`timezone` 

1736 The time zone to use in labeling dates. 

1737 

1738 xdate : bool, default: True 

1739 If *True*, the *x*-axis will be interpreted as Matplotlib dates. 

1740 

1741 ydate : bool, default: False 

1742 If *True*, the *y*-axis will be interpreted as Matplotlib dates. 

1743 

1744 Returns 

1745 ------- 

1746 list of `.Line2D` 

1747 Objects representing the plotted data. 

1748 

1749 Other Parameters 

1750 ---------------- 

1751 data : indexable object, optional 

1752 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

1753 **kwargs 

1754 Keyword arguments control the `.Line2D` properties: 

1755 

1756 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s 

1757 

1758 See Also 

1759 -------- 

1760 matplotlib.dates : Helper functions on dates. 

1761 matplotlib.dates.date2num : Convert dates to num. 

1762 matplotlib.dates.num2date : Convert num to dates. 

1763 matplotlib.dates.drange : Create an equally spaced sequence of dates. 

1764 

1765 Notes 

1766 ----- 

1767 If you are using custom date tickers and formatters, it may be 

1768 necessary to set the formatters/locators after the call to 

1769 `.plot_date`. `.plot_date` will set the default tick locator to 

1770 `.AutoDateLocator` (if the tick locator is not already set to a 

1771 `.DateLocator` instance) and the default tick formatter to 

1772 `.AutoDateFormatter` (if the tick formatter is not already set to a 

1773 `.DateFormatter` instance). 

1774 """ 

1775 if xdate: 

1776 self.xaxis_date(tz) 

1777 if ydate: 

1778 self.yaxis_date(tz) 

1779 return self.plot(x, y, fmt, **kwargs) 

1780 

1781 # @_preprocess_data() # let 'plot' do the unpacking.. 

1782 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

1783 def loglog(self, *args, **kwargs): 

1784 """ 

1785 Make a plot with log scaling on both the x- and y-axis. 

1786 

1787 Call signatures:: 

1788 

1789 loglog([x], y, [fmt], data=None, **kwargs) 

1790 loglog([x], y, [fmt], [x2], y2, [fmt2], ..., **kwargs) 

1791 

1792 This is just a thin wrapper around `.plot` which additionally changes 

1793 both the x-axis and the y-axis to log scaling. All the concepts and 

1794 parameters of plot can be used here as well. 

1795 

1796 The additional parameters *base*, *subs* and *nonpositive* control the 

1797 x/y-axis properties. They are just forwarded to `.Axes.set_xscale` and 

1798 `.Axes.set_yscale`. To use different properties on the x-axis and the 

1799 y-axis, use e.g. 

1800 ``ax.set_xscale("log", base=10); ax.set_yscale("log", base=2)``. 

1801 

1802 Parameters 

1803 ---------- 

1804 base : float, default: 10 

1805 Base of the logarithm. 

1806 

1807 subs : sequence, optional 

1808 The location of the minor ticks. If *None*, reasonable locations 

1809 are automatically chosen depending on the number of decades in the 

1810 plot. See `.Axes.set_xscale`/`.Axes.set_yscale` for details. 

1811 

1812 nonpositive : {'mask', 'clip'}, default: 'mask' 

1813 Non-positive values can be masked as invalid, or clipped to a very 

1814 small positive number. 

1815 

1816 **kwargs 

1817 All parameters supported by `.plot`. 

1818 

1819 Returns 

1820 ------- 

1821 list of `.Line2D` 

1822 Objects representing the plotted data. 

1823 """ 

1824 dx = {k: v for k, v in kwargs.items() 

1825 if k in ['base', 'subs', 'nonpositive', 

1826 'basex', 'subsx', 'nonposx']} 

1827 self.set_xscale('log', **dx) 

1828 dy = {k: v for k, v in kwargs.items() 

1829 if k in ['base', 'subs', 'nonpositive', 

1830 'basey', 'subsy', 'nonposy']} 

1831 self.set_yscale('log', **dy) 

1832 return self.plot( 

1833 *args, **{k: v for k, v in kwargs.items() if k not in {*dx, *dy}}) 

1834 

1835 # @_preprocess_data() # let 'plot' do the unpacking.. 

1836 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

1837 def semilogx(self, *args, **kwargs): 

1838 """ 

1839 Make a plot with log scaling on the x-axis. 

1840 

1841 Call signatures:: 

1842 

1843 semilogx([x], y, [fmt], data=None, **kwargs) 

1844 semilogx([x], y, [fmt], [x2], y2, [fmt2], ..., **kwargs) 

1845 

1846 This is just a thin wrapper around `.plot` which additionally changes 

1847 the x-axis to log scaling. All the concepts and parameters of plot can 

1848 be used here as well. 

1849 

1850 The additional parameters *base*, *subs*, and *nonpositive* control the 

1851 x-axis properties. They are just forwarded to `.Axes.set_xscale`. 

1852 

1853 Parameters 

1854 ---------- 

1855 base : float, default: 10 

1856 Base of the x logarithm. 

1857 

1858 subs : array-like, optional 

1859 The location of the minor xticks. If *None*, reasonable locations 

1860 are automatically chosen depending on the number of decades in the 

1861 plot. See `.Axes.set_xscale` for details. 

1862 

1863 nonpositive : {'mask', 'clip'}, default: 'mask' 

1864 Non-positive values in x can be masked as invalid, or clipped to a 

1865 very small positive number. 

1866 

1867 **kwargs 

1868 All parameters supported by `.plot`. 

1869 

1870 Returns 

1871 ------- 

1872 list of `.Line2D` 

1873 Objects representing the plotted data. 

1874 """ 

1875 d = {k: v for k, v in kwargs.items() 

1876 if k in ['base', 'subs', 'nonpositive', 

1877 'basex', 'subsx', 'nonposx']} 

1878 self.set_xscale('log', **d) 

1879 return self.plot( 

1880 *args, **{k: v for k, v in kwargs.items() if k not in d}) 

1881 

1882 # @_preprocess_data() # let 'plot' do the unpacking.. 

1883 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

1884 def semilogy(self, *args, **kwargs): 

1885 """ 

1886 Make a plot with log scaling on the y-axis. 

1887 

1888 Call signatures:: 

1889 

1890 semilogy([x], y, [fmt], data=None, **kwargs) 

1891 semilogy([x], y, [fmt], [x2], y2, [fmt2], ..., **kwargs) 

1892 

1893 This is just a thin wrapper around `.plot` which additionally changes 

1894 the y-axis to log scaling. All the concepts and parameters of plot can 

1895 be used here as well. 

1896 

1897 The additional parameters *base*, *subs*, and *nonpositive* control the 

1898 y-axis properties. They are just forwarded to `.Axes.set_yscale`. 

1899 

1900 Parameters 

1901 ---------- 

1902 base : float, default: 10 

1903 Base of the y logarithm. 

1904 

1905 subs : array-like, optional 

1906 The location of the minor yticks. If *None*, reasonable locations 

1907 are automatically chosen depending on the number of decades in the 

1908 plot. See `.Axes.set_yscale` for details. 

1909 

1910 nonpositive : {'mask', 'clip'}, default: 'mask' 

1911 Non-positive values in y can be masked as invalid, or clipped to a 

1912 very small positive number. 

1913 

1914 **kwargs 

1915 All parameters supported by `.plot`. 

1916 

1917 Returns 

1918 ------- 

1919 list of `.Line2D` 

1920 Objects representing the plotted data. 

1921 """ 

1922 d = {k: v for k, v in kwargs.items() 

1923 if k in ['base', 'subs', 'nonpositive', 

1924 'basey', 'subsy', 'nonposy']} 

1925 self.set_yscale('log', **d) 

1926 return self.plot( 

1927 *args, **{k: v for k, v in kwargs.items() if k not in d}) 

1928 

1929 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x"], label_namer="x") 

1930 def acorr(self, x, **kwargs): 

1931 """ 

1932 Plot the autocorrelation of *x*. 

1933 

1934 Parameters 

1935 ---------- 

1936 x : array-like 

1937 

1938 detrend : callable, default: `.mlab.detrend_none` (no detrending) 

1939 A detrending function applied to *x*. It must have the 

1940 signature :: 

1941 

1942 detrend(x: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray 

1943 

1944 normed : bool, default: True 

1945 If ``True``, input vectors are normalised to unit length. 

1946 

1947 usevlines : bool, default: True 

1948 Determines the plot style. 

1949 

1950 If ``True``, vertical lines are plotted from 0 to the acorr value 

1951 using `.Axes.vlines`. Additionally, a horizontal line is plotted 

1952 at y=0 using `.Axes.axhline`. 

1953 

1954 If ``False``, markers are plotted at the acorr values using 

1955 `.Axes.plot`. 

1956 

1957 maxlags : int, default: 10 

1958 Number of lags to show. If ``None``, will return all 

1959 ``2 * len(x) - 1`` lags. 

1960 

1961 Returns 

1962 ------- 

1963 lags : array (length ``2*maxlags+1``) 

1964 The lag vector. 

1965 c : array (length ``2*maxlags+1``) 

1966 The auto correlation vector. 

1967 line : `.LineCollection` or `.Line2D` 

1968 `.Artist` added to the Axes of the correlation: 

1969 

1970 - `.LineCollection` if *usevlines* is True. 

1971 - `.Line2D` if *usevlines* is False. 

1972 b : `.Line2D` or None 

1973 Horizontal line at 0 if *usevlines* is True 

1974 None *usevlines* is False. 

1975 

1976 Other Parameters 

1977 ---------------- 

1978 linestyle : `.Line2D` property, optional 

1979 The linestyle for plotting the data points. 

1980 Only used if *usevlines* is ``False``. 

1981 

1982 marker : str, default: 'o' 

1983 The marker for plotting the data points. 

1984 Only used if *usevlines* is ``False``. 

1985 

1986 data : indexable object, optional 

1987 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

1988 

1989 **kwargs 

1990 Additional parameters are passed to `.Axes.vlines` and 

1991 `.Axes.axhline` if *usevlines* is ``True``; otherwise they are 

1992 passed to `.Axes.plot`. 

1993 

1994 Notes 

1995 ----- 

1996 The cross correlation is performed with `numpy.correlate` with 

1997 ``mode = "full"``. 

1998 """ 

1999 return self.xcorr(x, x, **kwargs) 

2000 

2001 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x", "y"], label_namer="y") 

2002 def xcorr(self, x, y, normed=True, detrend=mlab.detrend_none, 

2003 usevlines=True, maxlags=10, **kwargs): 

2004 r""" 

2005 Plot the cross correlation between *x* and *y*. 

2006 

2007 The correlation with lag k is defined as 

2008 :math:`\sum_n x[n+k] \cdot y^*[n]`, where :math:`y^*` is the complex 

2009 conjugate of :math:`y`. 

2010 

2011 Parameters 

2012 ---------- 

2013 x, y : array-like of length n 

2014 

2015 detrend : callable, default: `.mlab.detrend_none` (no detrending) 

2016 A detrending function applied to *x* and *y*. It must have the 

2017 signature :: 

2018 

2019 detrend(x: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray 

2020 

2021 normed : bool, default: True 

2022 If ``True``, input vectors are normalised to unit length. 

2023 

2024 usevlines : bool, default: True 

2025 Determines the plot style. 

2026 

2027 If ``True``, vertical lines are plotted from 0 to the xcorr value 

2028 using `.Axes.vlines`. Additionally, a horizontal line is plotted 

2029 at y=0 using `.Axes.axhline`. 

2030 

2031 If ``False``, markers are plotted at the xcorr values using 

2032 `.Axes.plot`. 

2033 

2034 maxlags : int, default: 10 

2035 Number of lags to show. If None, will return all ``2 * len(x) - 1`` 

2036 lags. 

2037 

2038 Returns 

2039 ------- 

2040 lags : array (length ``2*maxlags+1``) 

2041 The lag vector. 

2042 c : array (length ``2*maxlags+1``) 

2043 The auto correlation vector. 

2044 line : `.LineCollection` or `.Line2D` 

2045 `.Artist` added to the Axes of the correlation: 

2046 

2047 - `.LineCollection` if *usevlines* is True. 

2048 - `.Line2D` if *usevlines* is False. 

2049 b : `.Line2D` or None 

2050 Horizontal line at 0 if *usevlines* is True 

2051 None *usevlines* is False. 

2052 

2053 Other Parameters 

2054 ---------------- 

2055 linestyle : `.Line2D` property, optional 

2056 The linestyle for plotting the data points. 

2057 Only used if *usevlines* is ``False``. 

2058 

2059 marker : str, default: 'o' 

2060 The marker for plotting the data points. 

2061 Only used if *usevlines* is ``False``. 

2062 

2063 data : indexable object, optional 

2064 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

2065 

2066 **kwargs 

2067 Additional parameters are passed to `.Axes.vlines` and 

2068 `.Axes.axhline` if *usevlines* is ``True``; otherwise they are 

2069 passed to `.Axes.plot`. 

2070 

2071 Notes 

2072 ----- 

2073 The cross correlation is performed with `numpy.correlate` with 

2074 ``mode = "full"``. 

2075 """ 

2076 Nx = len(x) 

2077 if Nx != len(y): 2077 ↛ 2078line 2077 didn't jump to line 2078, because the condition on line 2077 was never true

2078 raise ValueError('x and y must be equal length') 

2079 

2080 x = detrend(np.asarray(x)) 

2081 y = detrend(np.asarray(y)) 

2082 

2083 correls = np.correlate(x, y, mode="full") 

2084 

2085 if normed: 2085 ↛ 2088line 2085 didn't jump to line 2088, because the condition on line 2085 was never false

2086 correls /= np.sqrt(np.dot(x, x) * np.dot(y, y)) 

2087 

2088 if maxlags is None: 2088 ↛ 2089line 2088 didn't jump to line 2089, because the condition on line 2088 was never true

2089 maxlags = Nx - 1 

2090 

2091 if maxlags >= Nx or maxlags < 1: 2091 ↛ 2092line 2091 didn't jump to line 2092, because the condition on line 2091 was never true

2092 raise ValueError('maxlags must be None or strictly ' 

2093 'positive < %d' % Nx) 

2094 

2095 lags = np.arange(-maxlags, maxlags + 1) 

2096 correls = correls[Nx - 1 - maxlags:Nx + maxlags] 

2097 

2098 if usevlines: 2098 ↛ 2104line 2098 didn't jump to line 2104, because the condition on line 2098 was never false

2099 a = self.vlines(lags, [0], correls, **kwargs) 

2100 # Make label empty so only vertical lines get a legend entry 

2101 kwargs.pop('label', '') 

2102 b = self.axhline(**kwargs) 

2103 else: 

2104 kwargs.setdefault('marker', 'o') 

2105 kwargs.setdefault('linestyle', 'None') 

2106 a, = self.plot(lags, correls, **kwargs) 

2107 b = None 

2108 return lags, correls, a, b 

2109 

2110 #### Specialized plotting 

2111 

2112 # @_preprocess_data() # let 'plot' do the unpacking.. 

2113 def step(self, x, y, *args, where='pre', data=None, **kwargs): 

2114 """ 

2115 Make a step plot. 

2116 

2117 Call signatures:: 

2118 

2119 step(x, y, [fmt], *, data=None, where='pre', **kwargs) 

2120 step(x, y, [fmt], x2, y2, [fmt2], ..., *, where='pre', **kwargs) 

2121 

2122 This is just a thin wrapper around `.plot` which changes some 

2123 formatting options. Most of the concepts and parameters of plot can be 

2124 used here as well. 

2125 

2126 .. note:: 

2127 

2128 This method uses a standard plot with a step drawstyle: The *x* 

2129 values are the reference positions and steps extend left/right/both 

2130 directions depending on *where*. 

2131 

2132 For the common case where you know the values and edges of the 

2133 steps, use `~.Axes.stairs` instead. 

2134 

2135 Parameters 

2136 ---------- 

2137 x : array-like 

2138 1D sequence of x positions. It is assumed, but not checked, that 

2139 it is uniformly increasing. 

2140 

2141 y : array-like 

2142 1D sequence of y levels. 

2143 

2144 fmt : str, optional 

2145 A format string, e.g. 'g' for a green line. See `.plot` for a more 

2146 detailed description. 

2147 

2148 Note: While full format strings are accepted, it is recommended to 

2149 only specify the color. Line styles are currently ignored (use 

2150 the keyword argument *linestyle* instead). Markers are accepted 

2151 and plotted on the given positions, however, this is a rarely 

2152 needed feature for step plots. 

2153 

2154 where : {'pre', 'post', 'mid'}, default: 'pre' 

2155 Define where the steps should be placed: 

2156 

2157 - 'pre': The y value is continued constantly to the left from 

2158 every *x* position, i.e. the interval ``(x[i-1], x[i]]`` has the 

2159 value ``y[i]``. 

2160 - 'post': The y value is continued constantly to the right from 

2161 every *x* position, i.e. the interval ``[x[i], x[i+1])`` has the 

2162 value ``y[i]``. 

2163 - 'mid': Steps occur half-way between the *x* positions. 

2164 

2165 data : indexable object, optional 

2166 An object with labelled data. If given, provide the label names to 

2167 plot in *x* and *y*. 

2168 

2169 **kwargs 

2170 Additional parameters are the same as those for `.plot`. 

2171 

2172 Returns 

2173 ------- 

2174 list of `.Line2D` 

2175 Objects representing the plotted data. 

2176 """ 

2177 _api.check_in_list(('pre', 'post', 'mid'), where=where) 

2178 kwargs['drawstyle'] = 'steps-' + where 

2179 return self.plot(x, y, *args, data=data, **kwargs) 

2180 

2181 @staticmethod 

2182 def _convert_dx(dx, x0, xconv, convert): 

2183 """ 

2184 Small helper to do logic of width conversion flexibly. 

2185 

2186 *dx* and *x0* have units, but *xconv* has already been converted 

2187 to unitless (and is an ndarray). This allows the *dx* to have units 

2188 that are different from *x0*, but are still accepted by the 

2189 ``__add__`` operator of *x0*. 

2190 """ 

2191 

2192 # x should be an array... 

2193 assert type(xconv) is np.ndarray 

2194 

2195 if xconv.size == 0: 

2196 # xconv has already been converted, but maybe empty... 

2197 return convert(dx) 

2198 

2199 try: 

2200 # attempt to add the width to x0; this works for 

2201 # datetime+timedelta, for instance 

2202 

2203 # only use the first element of x and x0. This saves 

2204 # having to be sure addition works across the whole 

2205 # vector. This is particularly an issue if 

2206 # x0 and dx are lists so x0 + dx just concatenates the lists. 

2207 # We can't just cast x0 and dx to numpy arrays because that 

2208 # removes the units from unit packages like `pint` that 

2209 # wrap numpy arrays. 

2210 try: 

2211 x0 = cbook._safe_first_finite(x0) 

2212 except (TypeError, IndexError, KeyError): 

2213 pass 

2214 except StopIteration: 

2215 # this means we found no finite element, fall back to first 

2216 # element unconditionally 

2217 x0 = cbook.safe_first_element(x0) 

2218 

2219 try: 

2220 x = cbook._safe_first_finite(xconv) 

2221 except (TypeError, IndexError, KeyError): 

2222 x = xconv 

2223 except StopIteration: 

2224 # this means we found no finite element, fall back to first 

2225 # element unconditionally 

2226 x = cbook.safe_first_element(xconv) 

2227 

2228 delist = False 

2229 if not np.iterable(dx): 

2230 dx = [dx] 

2231 delist = True 

2232 dx = [convert(x0 + ddx) - x for ddx in dx] 

2233 if delist: 

2234 dx = dx[0] 

2235 except (ValueError, TypeError, AttributeError): 

2236 # if the above fails (for any reason) just fallback to what 

2237 # we do by default and convert dx by itself. 

2238 dx = convert(dx) 

2239 return dx 

2240 

2241 @_preprocess_data() 

2242 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

2243 def bar(self, x, height, width=0.8, bottom=None, *, align="center", 

2244 **kwargs): 

2245 r""" 

2246 Make a bar plot. 

2247 

2248 The bars are positioned at *x* with the given *align*\ment. Their 

2249 dimensions are given by *height* and *width*. The vertical baseline 

2250 is *bottom* (default 0). 

2251 

2252 Many parameters can take either a single value applying to all bars 

2253 or a sequence of values, one for each bar. 

2254 

2255 Parameters 

2256 ---------- 

2257 x : float or array-like 

2258 The x coordinates of the bars. See also *align* for the 

2259 alignment of the bars to the coordinates. 

2260 

2261 height : float or array-like 

2262 The height(s) of the bars. 

2263 

2264 width : float or array-like, default: 0.8 

2265 The width(s) of the bars. 

2266 

2267 bottom : float or array-like, default: 0 

2268 The y coordinate(s) of the bottom side(s) of the bars. 

2269 

2270 align : {'center', 'edge'}, default: 'center' 

2271 Alignment of the bars to the *x* coordinates: 

2272
