6285 ---------- 

6286 C : array-like 

6287 The image data. Supported array shapes are: 

6288 

6289 - (M, N): an image with scalar data. Color-mapping is controlled 

6290 by *cmap*, *norm*, *vmin*, and *vmax*. 

6291 - (M, N, 3): an image with RGB values (0-1 float or 0-255 int). 

6292 - (M, N, 4): an image with RGBA values (0-1 float or 0-255 int), 

6293 i.e. including transparency. 

6294 

6295 The first two dimensions (M, N) define the rows and columns of 

6296 the image. 

6297 

6298 This parameter can only be passed positionally. 

6299 

6300 X, Y : tuple or array-like, default: ``(0, N)``, ``(0, M)`` 

6301 *X* and *Y* are used to specify the coordinates of the 

6302 quadrilaterals. There are different ways to do this: 

6303 

6304 - Use tuples ``X=(xmin, xmax)`` and ``Y=(ymin, ymax)`` to define 

6305 a *uniform rectangular grid*. 

6306 

6307 The tuples define the outer edges of the grid. All individual 

6308 quadrilaterals will be of the same size. This is the fastest 

6309 version. 

6310 

6311 - Use 1D arrays *X*, *Y* to specify a *non-uniform rectangular 

6312 grid*. 

6313 

6314 In this case *X* and *Y* have to be monotonic 1D arrays of length 

6315 *N+1* and *M+1*, specifying the x and y boundaries of the cells. 

6316 

6317 The speed is intermediate. Note: The grid is checked, and if 

6318 found to be uniform the fast version is used. 

6319 

6320 - Use 2D arrays *X*, *Y* if you need an *arbitrary quadrilateral 

6321 grid* (i.e. if the quadrilaterals are not rectangular). 

6322 

6323 In this case *X* and *Y* are 2D arrays with shape (M + 1, N + 1), 

6324 specifying the x and y coordinates of the corners of the colored 

6325 quadrilaterals. 

6326 

6327 This is the most general, but the slowest to render. It may 

6328 produce faster and more compact output using ps, pdf, and 

6329 svg backends, however. 

6330 

6331 These arguments can only be passed positionally. 

6332 

6333 %(cmap_doc)s 

6334 

6335 This parameter is ignored if *C* is RGB(A). 

6336 

6337 %(norm_doc)s 

6338 

6339 This parameter is ignored if *C* is RGB(A). 

6340 

6341 %(vmin_vmax_doc)s 

6342 

6343 This parameter is ignored if *C* is RGB(A). 

6344 

6345 alpha : float, default: None 

6346 The alpha blending value, between 0 (transparent) and 1 (opaque). 

6347 

6348 snap : bool, default: False 

6349 Whether to snap the mesh to pixel boundaries. 

6350 

6351 Returns 

6352 ------- 

6353 `.AxesImage` or `.PcolorImage` or `.QuadMesh` 

6354 The return type depends on the type of grid: 

6355 

6356 - `.AxesImage` for a regular rectangular grid. 

6357 - `.PcolorImage` for a non-regular rectangular grid. 

6358 - `.QuadMesh` for a non-rectangular grid. 

6359 

6360 Other Parameters 

6361 ---------------- 

6362 data : indexable object, optional 

6363 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

6364 

6365 **kwargs 

6366 Supported additional parameters depend on the type of grid. 

6367 See return types of *image* for further description. 

6368 """ 

6369 

6370 C = args[-1] 

6371 nr, nc = np.shape(C)[:2] 

6372 if len(args) == 1: 

6373 style = "image" 

6374 x = [0, nc] 

6375 y = [0, nr] 

6376 elif len(args) == 3: 6376 ↛ 6396line 6376 didn't jump to line 6396, because the condition on line 6376 was never false

6377 x, y = args[:2] 

6378 x = np.asarray(x) 

6379 y = np.asarray(y) 

6380 if x.ndim == 1 and y.ndim == 1: 

6381 if x.size == 2 and y.size == 2: 

6382 style = "image" 

6383 else: 

6384 dx = np.diff(x) 

6385 dy = np.diff(y) 

6386 if (np.ptp(dx) < 0.01 * abs(dx.mean()) and 

6387 np.ptp(dy) < 0.01 * abs(dy.mean())): 

6388 style = "image" 

6389 else: 

6390 style = "pcolorimage" 

6391 elif x.ndim == 2 and y.ndim == 2: 6391 ↛ 6394line 6391 didn't jump to line 6394, because the condition on line 6391 was never false

6392 style = "quadmesh" 

6393 else: 

6394 raise TypeError("arguments do not match valid signatures") 

6395 else: 

6396 raise TypeError("need 1 argument or 3 arguments") 

6397 

6398 if style == "quadmesh": 

6399 # data point in each cell is value at lower left corner 

6400 coords = np.stack([x, y], axis=-1) 

6401 if np.ndim(C) not in {2, 3}: 6401 ↛ 6402line 6401 didn't jump to line 6402, because the condition on line 6401 was never true

6402 raise ValueError("C must be 2D or 3D") 

6403 collection = mcoll.QuadMesh( 

6404 coords, array=C, 

6405 alpha=alpha, cmap=cmap, norm=norm, 

6406 antialiased=False, edgecolors="none") 

6407 self.add_collection(collection, autolim=False) 

6408 xl, xr, yb, yt = x.min(), x.max(), y.min(), y.max() 

6409 ret = collection 

6410 

6411 else: # It's one of the two image styles. 

6412 extent = xl, xr, yb, yt = x[0], x[-1], y[0], y[-1] 

6413 if style == "image": 

6414 im = mimage.AxesImage( 

6415 self, cmap=cmap, norm=norm, 

6416 data=C, alpha=alpha, extent=extent, 

6417 interpolation='nearest', origin='lower', 

6418 **kwargs) 

6419 elif style == "pcolorimage": 6419 ↛ 6424line 6419 didn't jump to line 6424, because the condition on line 6419 was never false

6420 im = mimage.PcolorImage( 

6421 self, x, y, C, 

6422 cmap=cmap, norm=norm, alpha=alpha, extent=extent, 

6423 **kwargs) 

6424 self.add_image(im) 

6425 ret = im 

6426 

6427 if np.ndim(C) == 2: # C.ndim == 3 is RGB(A) so doesn't need scaling. 

6428 ret._scale_norm(norm, vmin, vmax) 

6429 

6430 if ret.get_clip_path() is None: 6430 ↛ 6434line 6430 didn't jump to line 6434, because the condition on line 6430 was never false

6431 # image does not already have clipping set, clip to axes patch 

6432 ret.set_clip_path(self.patch) 

6433 

6434 ret.sticky_edges.x[:] = [xl, xr] 

6435 ret.sticky_edges.y[:] = [yb, yt] 

6436 self.update_datalim(np.array([[xl, yb], [xr, yt]])) 

6437 self._request_autoscale_view(tight=True) 

6438 return ret 

6439 

6440 @_preprocess_data() 

6441 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

6442 def contour(self, *args, **kwargs): 

6443 """ 

6444 Plot contour lines. 

6445 

6446 Call signature:: 

6447 

6448 contour([X, Y,] Z, [levels], **kwargs) 

6449 %(contour_doc)s 

6450 """ 

6451 kwargs['filled'] = False 

6452 contours = mcontour.QuadContourSet(self, *args, **kwargs) 

6453 self._request_autoscale_view() 

6454 return contours 

6455 

6456 @_preprocess_data() 

6457 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

6458 def contourf(self, *args, **kwargs): 

6459 """ 

6460 Plot filled contours. 

6461 

6462 Call signature:: 

6463 

6464 contourf([X, Y,] Z, [levels], **kwargs) 

6465 %(contour_doc)s 

6466 """ 

6467 kwargs['filled'] = True 

6468 contours = mcontour.QuadContourSet(self, *args, **kwargs) 

6469 self._request_autoscale_view() 

6470 return contours 

6471 

6472 def clabel(self, CS, levels=None, **kwargs): 

6473 """ 

6474 Label a contour plot. 

6475 

6476 Adds labels to line contours in given `.ContourSet`. 

6477 

6478 Parameters 

6479 ---------- 

6480 CS : `.ContourSet` instance 

6481 Line contours to label. 

6482 

6483 levels : array-like, optional 

6484 A list of level values, that should be labeled. The list must be 

6485 a subset of ``CS.levels``. If not given, all levels are labeled. 

6486 

6487 **kwargs 

6488 All other parameters are documented in `~.ContourLabeler.clabel`. 

6489 """ 

6490 return CS.clabel(levels, **kwargs) 

6491 

6492 #### Data analysis 

6493 

6494 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x", 'weights'], label_namer="x") 

6495 def hist(self, x, bins=None, range=None, density=False, weights=None, 

6496 cumulative=False, bottom=None, histtype='bar', align='mid', 

6497 orientation='vertical', rwidth=None, log=False, 

6498 color=None, label=None, stacked=False, **kwargs): 

6499 """ 

6500 Compute and plot a histogram. 

6501 

6502 This method uses `numpy.histogram` to bin the data in *x* and count the 

6503 number of values in each bin, then draws the distribution either as a 

6504 `.BarContainer` or `.Polygon`. The *bins*, *range*, *density*, and 

6505 *weights* parameters are forwarded to `numpy.histogram`. 

6506 

6507 If the data has already been binned and counted, use `~.bar` or 

6508 `~.stairs` to plot the distribution:: 

6509 

6510 counts, bins = np.histogram(x) 

6511 plt.stairs(counts, bins) 

6512 

6513 Alternatively, plot pre-computed bins and counts using ``hist()`` by 

6514 treating each bin as a single point with a weight equal to its count:: 

6515 

6516 plt.hist(bins[:-1], bins, weights=counts) 

6517 

6518 The data input *x* can be a singular array, a list of datasets of 

6519 potentially different lengths ([*x0*, *x1*, ...]), or a 2D ndarray in 

6520 which each column is a dataset. Note that the ndarray form is 

6521 transposed relative to the list form. If the input is an array, then 

6522 the return value is a tuple (*n*, *bins*, *patches*); if the input is a 

6523 sequence of arrays, then the return value is a tuple 

6524 ([*n0*, *n1*, ...], *bins*, [*patches0*, *patches1*, ...]). 

6525 

6526 Masked arrays are not supported. 

6527 

6528 Parameters 

6529 ---------- 

6530 x : (n,) array or sequence of (n,) arrays 

6531 Input values, this takes either a single array or a sequence of 

6532 arrays which are not required to be of the same length. 

6533 

6534 bins : int or sequence or str, default: :rc:`hist.bins` 

6535 If *bins* is an integer, it defines the number of equal-width bins 

6536 in the range. 

6537 

6538 If *bins* is a sequence, it defines the bin edges, including the 

6539 left edge of the first bin and the right edge of the last bin; 

6540 in this case, bins may be unequally spaced. All but the last 

6541 (righthand-most) bin is half-open. In other words, if *bins* is:: 

6542 

6543 [1, 2, 3, 4] 

6544 

6545 then the first bin is ``[1, 2)`` (including 1, but excluding 2) and 

6546 the second ``[2, 3)``. The last bin, however, is ``[3, 4]``, which 

6547 *includes* 4. 

6548 

6549 If *bins* is a string, it is one of the binning strategies 

6550 supported by `numpy.histogram_bin_edges`: 'auto', 'fd', 'doane', 

6551 'scott', 'stone', 'rice', 'sturges', or 'sqrt'. 

6552 

6553 range : tuple or None, default: None 

6554 The lower and upper range of the bins. Lower and upper outliers 

6555 are ignored. If not provided, *range* is ``(x.min(), x.max())``. 

6556 Range has no effect if *bins* is a sequence. 

6557 

6558 If *bins* is a sequence or *range* is specified, autoscaling 

6559 is based on the specified bin range instead of the 

6560 range of x. 

6561 

6562 density : bool, default: False 

6563 If ``True``, draw and return a probability density: each bin 

6564 will display the bin's raw count divided by the total number of 

6565 counts *and the bin width* 

6566 (``density = counts / (sum(counts) * np.diff(bins))``), 

6567 so that the area under the histogram integrates to 1 

6568 (``np.sum(density * np.diff(bins)) == 1``). 

6569 

6570 If *stacked* is also ``True``, the sum of the histograms is 

6571 normalized to 1. 

6572 

6573 weights : (n,) array-like or None, default: None 

6574 An array of weights, of the same shape as *x*. Each value in 

6575 *x* only contributes its associated weight towards the bin count 

6576 (instead of 1). If *density* is ``True``, the weights are 

6577 normalized, so that the integral of the density over the range 

6578 remains 1. 

6579 

6580 cumulative : bool or -1, default: False 

6581 If ``True``, then a histogram is computed where each bin gives the 

6582 counts in that bin plus all bins for smaller values. The last bin 

6583 gives the total number of datapoints. 

6584 

6585 If *density* is also ``True`` then the histogram is normalized such 

6586 that the last bin equals 1. 

6587 

6588 If *cumulative* is a number less than 0 (e.g., -1), the direction 

6589 of accumulation is reversed. In this case, if *density* is also 

6590 ``True``, then the histogram is normalized such that the first bin 

6591 equals 1. 

6592 

6593 bottom : array-like, scalar, or None, default: None 

6594 Location of the bottom of each bin, i.e. bins are drawn from 

6595 ``bottom`` to ``bottom + hist(x, bins)`` If a scalar, the bottom 

6596 of each bin is shifted by the same amount. If an array, each bin 

6597 is shifted independently and the length of bottom must match the 

6598 number of bins. If None, defaults to 0. 

6599 

6600 histtype : {'bar', 'barstacked', 'step', 'stepfilled'}, default: 'bar' 

6601 The type of histogram to draw. 

6602 

6603 - 'bar' is a traditional bar-type histogram. If multiple data 

6604 are given the bars are arranged side by side. 

6605 - 'barstacked' is a bar-type histogram where multiple 

6606 data are stacked on top of each other. 

6607 - 'step' generates a lineplot that is by default unfilled. 

6608 - 'stepfilled' generates a lineplot that is by default filled. 

6609 

6610 align : {'left', 'mid', 'right'}, default: 'mid' 

6611 The horizontal alignment of the histogram bars. 

6612 

6613 - 'left': bars are centered on the left bin edges. 

6614 - 'mid': bars are centered between the bin edges. 

6615 - 'right': bars are centered on the right bin edges. 

6616 

6617 orientation : {'vertical', 'horizontal'}, default: 'vertical' 

6618 If 'horizontal', `~.Axes.barh` will be used for bar-type histograms 

6619 and the *bottom* kwarg will be the left edges. 

6620 

6621 rwidth : float or None, default: None 

6622 The relative width of the bars as a fraction of the bin width. If 

6623 ``None``, automatically compute the width. 

6624 

6625 Ignored if *histtype* is 'step' or 'stepfilled'. 

6626 

6627 log : bool, default: False 

6628 If ``True``, the histogram axis will be set to a log scale. 

6629 

6630 color : color or array-like of colors or None, default: None 

6631 Color or sequence of colors, one per dataset. Default (``None``) 

6632 uses the standard line color sequence. 

6633 

6634 label : str or None, default: None 

6635 String, or sequence of strings to match multiple datasets. Bar 

6636 charts yield multiple patches per dataset, but only the first gets 

6637 the label, so that `~.Axes.legend` will work as expected. 

6638 

6639 stacked : bool, default: False 

6640 If ``True``, multiple data are stacked on top of each other If 

6641 ``False`` multiple data are arranged side by side if histtype is 

6642 'bar' or on top of each other if histtype is 'step' 

6643 

6644 Returns 

6645 ------- 

6646 n : array or list of arrays 

6647 The values of the histogram bins. See *density* and *weights* for a 

6648 description of the possible semantics. If input *x* is an array, 

6649 then this is an array of length *nbins*. If input is a sequence of 

6650 arrays ``[data1, data2, ...]``, then this is a list of arrays with 

6651 the values of the histograms for each of the arrays in the same 

6652 order. The dtype of the array *n* (or of its element arrays) will 

6653 always be float even if no weighting or normalization is used. 

6654 

6655 bins : array 

6656 The edges of the bins. Length nbins + 1 (nbins left edges and right 

6657 edge of last bin). Always a single array even when multiple data 

6658 sets are passed in. 

6659 

6660 patches : `.BarContainer` or list of a single `.Polygon` or list of \ 

6661such objects 

6662 Container of individual artists used to create the histogram 

6663 or list of such containers if there are multiple input datasets. 

6664 

6665 Other Parameters 

6666 ---------------- 

6667 data : indexable object, optional 

6668 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

6669 

6670 **kwargs 

6671 `~matplotlib.patches.Patch` properties 

6672 

6673 See Also 

6674 -------- 

6675 hist2d : 2D histogram with rectangular bins 

6676 hexbin : 2D histogram with hexagonal bins 

6677 

6678 Notes 

6679 ----- 

6680 For large numbers of bins (>1000), plotting can be significantly faster 

6681 if *histtype* is set to 'step' or 'stepfilled' rather than 'bar' or 

6682 'barstacked'. 

6683 """ 

6684 # Avoid shadowing the builtin. 

6685 bin_range = range 

6686 from builtins import range 

6687 

6688 if np.isscalar(x): 

6689 histBranchBools[0] = True 

6690 x = [x] 

6691 

6692 if bins is None: 

6693 histBranchBools[1] = True 

6694 bins = mpl.rcParams['hist.bins'] 

6695 

6696 # Validate string inputs here to avoid cluttering subsequent code. 

6697 _api.check_in_list(['bar', 'barstacked', 'step', 'stepfilled'], 

6698 histtype=histtype) 

6699 _api.check_in_list(['left', 'mid', 'right'], align=align) 

6700 _api.check_in_list(['horizontal', 'vertical'], orientation=orientation) 

6701 

6702 if histtype == 'barstacked' and not stacked: 

6703 histBranchBools[3] = True 

6704 stacked = True 

6705 

6706 # Massage 'x' for processing. 

6707 x = cbook._reshape_2D(x, 'x') 

6708 nx = len(x) # number of datasets 

6709 

6710 # Process unit information. _process_unit_info sets the unit and 

6711 # converts the first dataset; then we convert each following dataset 

6712 # one at a time. 

6713 if orientation == "vertical": 

6714 histBranchBools[4] = True 

6715 convert_units = self.convert_xunits 

6716 x = [*self._process_unit_info([("x", x[0])], kwargs), 

6717 *map(convert_units, x[1:])] 

6718 else: # horizontal 

6719 histBranchBools[5] = True 

6720 convert_units = self.convert_yunits 

6721 x = [*self._process_unit_info([("y", x[0])], kwargs), 

6722 *map(convert_units, x[1:])] 

6723 

6724 if bin_range is not None: 

6725 histBranchBools[6] = True 

6726 bin_range = convert_units(bin_range) 

6727 

6728 if not cbook.is_scalar_or_string(bins): 

6729 histBranchBools[7] = True 

6730 bins = convert_units(bins) 

6731 

6732 # We need to do to 'weights' what was done to 'x' 

6733 if weights is not None: 

6734 histBranchBools[8] = True 

6735 w = cbook._reshape_2D(weights, 'weights') 

6736 else: 

6737 histBranchBools[9] = True 

6738 w = [None] * nx 

6739 

6740 if len(w) != nx: 6740 ↛ 6741line 6740 didn't jump to line 6741, because the condition on line 6740 was never true

6741 histBranchBools[10] = True 

6742 raise ValueError('weights should have the same shape as x') 

6743 

6744 input_empty = True 

6745 for xi, wi in zip(x, w): 

6746 histBranchBools[11] = True 

6747 len_xi = len(xi) 

6748 if wi is not None and len(wi) != len_xi: 6748 ↛ 6749line 6748 didn't jump to line 6749, because the condition on line 6748 was never true

6749 histBranchBools[12] = True 

6750 raise ValueError('weights should have the same shape as x') 

6751 if len_xi: 

6752 histBranchBools[13] = True 

6753 input_empty = False 

6754 

6755 if color is None: 

6756 histBranchBools[14] = True 

6757 colors = [self._get_lines.get_next_color() for i in range(nx)] 

6758 else: 

6759 histBranchBools[15] = True 

6760 colors = mcolors.to_rgba_array(color) 

6761 if len(colors) != nx: 6761 ↛ 6762line 6761 didn't jump to line 6762, because the condition on line 6761 was never true

6762 histBranchBools[16] = True 

6763 raise ValueError(f"The 'color' keyword argument must have one " 

6764 f"color per dataset, but {nx} datasets and " 

6765 f"{len(colors)} colors were provided") 

6766 

6767 hist_kwargs = dict() 

6768 

6769 # if the bin_range is not given, compute without nan numpy 

6770 # does not do this for us when guessing the range (but will 

6771 # happily ignore nans when computing the histogram). 

6772 if bin_range is None: 

6773 histBranchBools[17] = True 

6774 xmin = np.inf 

6775 xmax = -np.inf 

6776 for xi in x: 

6777 histBranchBools[18] = True 

6778 if len(xi): 

6779 histBranchBools[19] = True 

6780 # python's min/max ignore nan, 

6781 # np.minnan returns nan for all nan input 

6782 xmin = min(xmin, np.nanmin(xi)) 

6783 xmax = max(xmax, np.nanmax(xi)) 

6784 if xmin <= xmax: # Only happens if we have seen a finite value. 

6785 histBranchBools[20] = True 

6786 bin_range = (xmin, xmax) 

6787 

6788 # If bins are not specified either explicitly or via range, 

6789 # we need to figure out the range required for all datasets, 

6790 # and supply that to np.histogram. 

6791 if not input_empty and len(x) > 1: 

6792 histBranchBools[21] = True 

6793 if weights is not None: 

6794 histBranchBools[22] = True 

6795 _w = np.concatenate(w) 

6796 else: 

6797 histBranchBools[23] = True 

6798 _w = None 

6799 bins = np.histogram_bin_edges( 

6800 np.concatenate(x), bins, bin_range, _w) 

6801 else: 

6802 histBranchBools[24] = True 

6803 hist_kwargs['range'] = bin_range 

6804 

6805 density = bool(density) 

6806 if density and not stacked: 

6807 histBranchBools[25] = True 

6808 hist_kwargs['density'] = density 

6809 

6810 # List to store all the top coordinates of the histograms 

6811 tops = [] # Will have shape (n_datasets, n_bins). 

6812 # Loop through datasets 

6813 for i in range(nx): 

6814 histBranchBools[26] = True 

6815 # this will automatically overwrite bins, 

6816 # so that each histogram uses the same bins 

6817 m, bins = np.histogram(x[i], bins, weights=w[i], **hist_kwargs) 

6818 tops.append(m) 

6819 tops = np.array(tops, float) # causes problems later if it's an int 

6820 bins = np.array(bins, float) # causes problems if float16 

6821 if stacked: 

6822 histBranchBools[27] = True 

6823 tops = tops.cumsum(axis=0) 

6824 # If a stacked density plot, normalize so the area of all the 

6825 # stacked histograms together is 1 

6826 if density: 

6827 histBranchBools[28] = True 

6828 tops = (tops / np.diff(bins)) / tops[-1].sum() 

6829 if cumulative: 6829 ↛ 6830line 6829 didn't jump to line 6830, because the condition on line 6829 was never true

6830 histBranchBools[29] = True 

6831 slc = slice(None) 

6832 if isinstance(cumulative, Number) and cumulative < 0: 

6833 histBranchBools[30] = True 

6834 slc = slice(None, None, -1) 

6835 if density: 

6836 histBranchBools[31] = True 

6837 tops = (tops * np.diff(bins))[:, slc].cumsum(axis=1)[:, slc] 

6838 else: 

6839 histBranchBools[32] = True 

6840 tops = tops[:, slc].cumsum(axis=1)[:, slc] 

6841 

6842 patches = [] 

6843 

6844 if histtype.startswith('bar'): 

6845 histBranchBools[33] = True 

6846 totwidth = np.diff(bins) 

6847 

6848 if rwidth is not None: 6848 ↛ 6849line 6848 didn't jump to line 6849, because the condition on line 6848 was never true

6849 histBranchBools[34] = True 

6850 dr = np.clip(rwidth, 0, 1) 

6851 elif (len(tops) > 1 and 

6852 ((not stacked) or mpl.rcParams['_internal.classic_mode'])): 

6853 dr = 0.8 

6854 histBranchBools[35] = True 

6855 else: 

6856 dr = 1.0 

6857 histBranchBools[36] = True 

6858 

6859 if histtype == 'bar' and not stacked: 

6860 histBranchBools[37] = True 

6861 width = dr * totwidth / nx 

6862 dw = width 

6863 boffset = -0.5 * dr * totwidth * (1 - 1 / nx) 

6864 elif histtype == 'barstacked' or stacked: 6864 ↛ 6869line 6864 didn't jump to line 6869, because the condition on line 6864 was never false

6865 histBranchBools[38] = True 

6866 width = dr * totwidth 

6867 boffset, dw = 0.0, 0.0 

6868 

6869 if align == 'mid': 6869 ↛ 6872line 6869 didn't jump to line 6872, because the condition on line 6869 was never false

6870 histBranchBools[39] = True 

6871 boffset += 0.5 * totwidth 

6872 elif align == 'right': 

6873 histBranchBools[40] = True 

6874 boffset += totwidth 

6875 

6876 if orientation == 'horizontal': 6876 ↛ 6877line 6876 didn't jump to line 6877, because the condition on line 6876 was never true

6877 histBranchBools[41] = True 

6878 _barfunc = self.barh 

6879 bottom_kwarg = 'left' 

6880 else: # orientation == 'vertical' 

6881 histBranchBools[42] = True 

6882 _barfunc = self.bar 

6883 bottom_kwarg = 'bottom' 

6884 

6885 for top, color in zip(tops, colors): 

6886 histBranchBools[43] = True 

6887 if bottom is None: 

6888 histBranchBools[44] = True 

6889 bottom = np.zeros(len(top)) 

6890 if stacked: 

6891 histBranchBools[45] = True 

6892 height = top - bottom 

6893 else: 

6894 histBranchBools[46] = True 

6895 height = top 

6896 bars = _barfunc(bins[:-1]+boffset, height, width, 

6897 align='center', log=log, 

6898 color=color, **{bottom_kwarg: bottom}) 

6899 patches.append(bars) 

6900 if stacked: 

6901 histBranchBools[47] = True 

6902 bottom = top 

6903 boffset += dw 

6904 # Remove stickies from all bars but the lowest ones, as otherwise 

6905 # margin expansion would be unable to cross the stickies in the 

6906 # middle of the bars. 

6907 for bars in patches[1:]: 

6908 histBranchBools[48] = True 

6909 for patch in bars: 

6910 histBranchBools[49] = True 

6911 patch.sticky_edges.x[:] = patch.sticky_edges.y[:] = [] 

6912 

6913 elif histtype.startswith('step'): 6913 ↛ 7004line 6913 didn't jump to line 7004, because the condition on line 6913 was never false

6914 histBranchBools[50] = True 

6915 # these define the perimeter of the polygon 

6916 x = np.zeros(4 * len(bins) - 3) 

6917 y = np.zeros(4 * len(bins) - 3) 

6918 

6919 x[0:2*len(bins)-1:2], x[1:2*len(bins)-1:2] = bins, bins[:-1] 

6920 x[2*len(bins)-1:] = x[1:2*len(bins)-1][::-1] 

6921 

6922 if bottom is None: 

6923 histBranchBools[51] = True 

6924 bottom = 0 

6925 

6926 y[1:2*len(bins)-1:2] = y[2:2*len(bins):2] = bottom 

6927 y[2*len(bins)-1:] = y[1:2*len(bins)-1][::-1] 

6928 

6929 if log: 

6930 histBranchBools[52] = True 

6931 if orientation == 'horizontal': 6931 ↛ 6932line 6931 didn't jump to line 6932, because the condition on line 6931 was never true

6932 histBranchBools[53] = True 

6933 self.set_xscale('log', nonpositive='clip') 

6934 else: # orientation == 'vertical' 

6935 histBranchBools[54] = True 

6936 self.set_yscale('log', nonpositive='clip') 

6937 

6938 if align == 'left': 6938 ↛ 6939line 6938 didn't jump to line 6939, because the condition on line 6938 was never true

6939 histBranchBools[55] = True 

6940 x -= 0.5*(bins[1]-bins[0]) 

6941 elif align == 'right': 6941 ↛ 6942line 6941 didn't jump to line 6942, because the condition on line 6941 was never true

6942 histBranchBools[56] = True 

6943 x += 0.5*(bins[1]-bins[0]) 

6944 

6945 # If fill kwarg is set, it will be passed to the patch collection, 

6946 # overriding this 

6947 fill = (histtype == 'stepfilled') 

6948 

6949 xvals, yvals = [], [] 

6950 for top in tops: 

6951 histBranchBools[57] = True 

6952 if stacked: 

6953 histBranchBools[58] = True 

6954 # top of the previous polygon becomes the bottom 

6955 y[2*len(bins)-1:] = y[1:2*len(bins)-1][::-1] 

6956 # set the top of this polygon 

6957 y[1:2*len(bins)-1:2] = y[2:2*len(bins):2] = top + bottom 

6958 

6959 # The starting point of the polygon has not yet been 

6960 # updated. So far only the endpoint was adjusted. This 

6961 # assignment closes the polygon. The redundant endpoint is 

6962 # later discarded (for step and stepfilled). 

6963 y[0] = y[-1] 

6964 

6965 if orientation == 'horizontal': 

6966 histBranchBools[59] = True 

6967 xvals.append(y.copy()) 

6968 yvals.append(x.copy()) 

6969 else: 

6970 histBranchBools[60] = True 

6971 xvals.append(x.copy()) 

6972 yvals.append(y.copy()) 

6973 

6974 # stepfill is closed, step is not 

6975 split = -1 if fill else 2 * len(bins) 

6976 # add patches in reverse order so that when stacking, 

6977 # items lower in the stack are plotted on top of 

6978 # items higher in the stack 

6979 for x, y, color in reversed(list(zip(xvals, yvals, colors))): 

6980 histBranchBools[61] = True 

6981 patches.append(self.fill( 

6982 x[:split], y[:split], 

6983 closed=True if fill else None, 

6984 facecolor=color, 

6985 edgecolor=None if fill else color, 

6986 fill=fill if fill else None, 

6987 zorder=None if fill else mlines.Line2D.zorder)) 

6988 for patch_list in patches: 

6989 histBranchBools[62] = True 

6990 for patch in patch_list: 

6991 histBranchBools[63] = True 

6992 if orientation == 'vertical': 

6993 histBranchBools[64] = True 

6994 patch.sticky_edges.y.append(0) 

6995 elif orientation == 'horizontal': 6995 ↛ 6990line 6995 didn't jump to line 6990, because the condition on line 6995 was never false

6996 histBranchBools[65] = True 

6997 patch.sticky_edges.x.append(0) 

6998 

6999 # we return patches, so put it back in the expected order 

7000 patches.reverse() 

7001 

7002 # If None, make all labels None (via zip_longest below); otherwise, 

7003 # cast each element to str, but keep a single str as it. 

7004 labels = [] if label is None else np.atleast_1d(np.asarray(label, str)) 

7005 for patch, lbl in itertools.zip_longest(patches, labels): 

7006 histBranchBools[66] = True 

7007 if patch: 7007 ↛ 7005line 7007 didn't jump to line 7005, because the condition on line 7007 was never false

7008 histBranchBools[67] = True 

7009 p = patch[0] 

7010 p._internal_update(kwargs) 

7011 if lbl is not None: 

7012 histBranchBools[68] = True 

7013 p.set_label(lbl) 

7014 for p in patch[1:]: 

7015 histBranchBools[69] = True 

7016 p._internal_update(kwargs) 

7017 p.set_label('_nolegend_') 

7018 

7019 if nx == 1: 

7020 histBranchBools[70] = True 

7021 return tops[0], bins, patches[0] 

7022 else: 

7023 histBranchBools[71] = True 

7024 patch_type = ("BarContainer" if histtype.startswith("bar") 

7025 else "list[Polygon]") 

7026 return tops, bins, cbook.silent_list(patch_type, patches) 

7027 

7028 @_preprocess_data() 

7029 def stairs(self, values, edges=None, *, 

7030 orientation='vertical', baseline=0, fill=False, **kwargs): 

7031 """ 

7032 A stepwise constant function as a line with bounding edges 

7033 or a filled plot. 

7034 

7035 Parameters 

7036 ---------- 

7037 values : array-like 

7038 The step heights. 

7039 

7040 edges : array-like 

7041 The edge positions, with ``len(edges) == len(vals) + 1``, 

7042 between which the curve takes on vals values. 

7043 

7044 orientation : {'vertical', 'horizontal'}, default: 'vertical' 

7045 The direction of the steps. Vertical means that *values* are along 

7046 the y-axis, and edges are along the x-axis. 

7047 

7048 baseline : float, array-like or None, default: 0 

7049 The bottom value of the bounding edges or when 

7050 ``fill=True``, position of lower edge. If *fill* is 

7051 True or an array is passed to *baseline*, a closed 

7052 path is drawn. 

7053 

7054 fill : bool, default: False 

7055 Whether the area under the step curve should be filled. 

7056 

7057 Returns 

7058 ------- 

7059 StepPatch : `matplotlib.patches.StepPatch` 

7060 

7061 Other Parameters 

7062 ---------------- 

7063 data : indexable object, optional 

7064 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

7065 

7066 **kwargs 

7067 `~matplotlib.patches.StepPatch` properties 

7068 

7069 """ 

7070 

7071 if 'color' in kwargs: 

7072 _color = kwargs.pop('color') 

7073 else: 

7074 _color = self._get_lines.get_next_color() 

7075 if fill: 

7076 kwargs.setdefault('linewidth', 0) 

7077 kwargs.setdefault('facecolor', _color) 

7078 else: 

7079 kwargs.setdefault('edgecolor', _color) 

7080 

7081 if edges is None: 

7082 edges = np.arange(len(values) + 1) 

7083 

7084 edges, values, baseline = self._process_unit_info( 

7085 [("x", edges), ("y", values), ("y", baseline)], kwargs) 

7086 

7087 patch = mpatches.StepPatch(values, 

7088 edges, 

7089 baseline=baseline, 

7090 orientation=orientation, 

7091 fill=fill, 

7092 **kwargs) 

7093 self.add_patch(patch) 

7094 if baseline is None: 

7095 baseline = 0 

7096 if orientation == 'vertical': 

7097 patch.sticky_edges.y.append(np.min(baseline)) 

7098 self.update_datalim([(edges[0], np.min(baseline))]) 

7099 else: 

7100 patch.sticky_edges.x.append(np.min(baseline)) 

7101 self.update_datalim([(np.min(baseline), edges[0])]) 

7102 self._request_autoscale_view() 

7103 return patch 

7104 

7105 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x", "y", "weights"]) 

7106 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

7107 def hist2d(self, x, y, bins=10, range=None, density=False, weights=None, 

7108 cmin=None, cmax=None, **kwargs): 

7109 """ 

7110 Make a 2D histogram plot. 

7111 

7112 Parameters 

7113 ---------- 

7114 x, y : array-like, shape (n, ) 

7115 Input values 

7116 

7117 bins : None or int or [int, int] or array-like or [array, array] 

7118 

7119 The bin specification: 

7120 

7121 - If int, the number of bins for the two dimensions 

7122 (nx=ny=bins). 

7123 - If ``[int, int]``, the number of bins in each dimension 

7124 (nx, ny = bins). 

7125 - If array-like, the bin edges for the two dimensions 

7126 (x_edges=y_edges=bins). 

7127 - If ``[array, array]``, the bin edges in each dimension 

7128 (x_edges, y_edges = bins). 

7129 

7130 The default value is 10. 

7131 

7132 range : array-like shape(2, 2), optional 

7133 The leftmost and rightmost edges of the bins along each dimension 

7134 (if not specified explicitly in the bins parameters): ``[[xmin, 

7135 xmax], [ymin, ymax]]``. All values outside of this range will be 

7136 considered outliers and not tallied in the histogram. 

7137 

7138 density : bool, default: False 

7139 Normalize histogram. See the documentation for the *density* 

7140 parameter of `~.Axes.hist` for more details. 

7141 

7142 weights : array-like, shape (n, ), optional 

7143 An array of values w_i weighing each sample (x_i, y_i). 

7144 

7145 cmin, cmax : float, default: None 

7146 All bins that has count less than *cmin* or more than *cmax* will 

7147 not be displayed (set to NaN before passing to imshow) and these 

7148 count values in the return value count histogram will also be set 

7149 to nan upon return. 

7150 

7151 Returns 

7152 ------- 

7153 h : 2D array 

7154 The bi-dimensional histogram of samples x and y. Values in x are 

7155 histogrammed along the first dimension and values in y are 

7156 histogrammed along the second dimension. 

7157 xedges : 1D array 

7158 The bin edges along the x-axis. 

7159 yedges : 1D array 

7160 The bin edges along the y-axis. 

7161 image : `~.matplotlib.collections.QuadMesh` 

7162 

7163 Other Parameters 

7164 ---------------- 

7165 %(cmap_doc)s 

7166 

7167 %(norm_doc)s 

7168 

7169 %(vmin_vmax_doc)s 

7170 

7171 alpha : ``0 <= scalar <= 1`` or ``None``, optional 

7172 The alpha blending value. 

7173 

7174 data : indexable object, optional 

7175 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

7176 

7177 **kwargs 

7178 Additional parameters are passed along to the 

7179 `~.Axes.pcolormesh` method and `~matplotlib.collections.QuadMesh` 

7180 constructor. 

7181 

7182 See Also 

7183 -------- 

7184 hist : 1D histogram plotting 

7185 hexbin : 2D histogram with hexagonal bins 

7186 

7187 Notes 

7188 ----- 

7189 - Currently ``hist2d`` calculates its own axis limits, and any limits 

7190 previously set are ignored. 

7191 - Rendering the histogram with a logarithmic color scale is 

7192 accomplished by passing a `.colors.LogNorm` instance to the *norm* 

7193 keyword argument. Likewise, power-law normalization (similar 

7194 in effect to gamma correction) can be accomplished with 

7195 `.colors.PowerNorm`. 

7196 """ 

7197 

7198 h, xedges, yedges = np.histogram2d(x, y, bins=bins, range=range, 

7199 density=density, weights=weights) 

7200 

7201 if cmin is not None: 7201 ↛ 7202line 7201 didn't jump to line 7202, because the condition on line 7201 was never true

7202 h[h < cmin] = None 

7203 if cmax is not None: 7203 ↛ 7204line 7203 didn't jump to line 7204, because the condition on line 7203 was never true

7204 h[h > cmax] = None 

7205 

7206 pc = self.pcolormesh(xedges, yedges, h.T, **kwargs) 

7207 self.set_xlim(xedges[0], xedges[-1]) 

7208 self.set_ylim(yedges[0], yedges[-1]) 

7209 

7210 return h, xedges, yedges, pc 

7211 

7212 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x"]) 

7213 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

7214 def psd(self, x, NFFT=None, Fs=None, Fc=None, detrend=None, 

7215 window=None, noverlap=None, pad_to=None, 

7216 sides=None, scale_by_freq=None, return_line=None, **kwargs): 

7217 r""" 

7218 Plot the power spectral density. 

7219 

7220 The power spectral density :math:`P_{xx}` by Welch's average 

7221 periodogram method. The vector *x* is divided into *NFFT* length 

7222 segments. Each segment is detrended by function *detrend* and 

7223 windowed by function *window*. *noverlap* gives the length of 

7224 the overlap between segments. The :math:`|\mathrm{fft}(i)|^2` 

7225 of each segment :math:`i` are averaged to compute :math:`P_{xx}`, 

7226 with a scaling to correct for power loss due to windowing. 

7227 

7228 If len(*x*) < *NFFT*, it will be zero padded to *NFFT*. 

7229 

7230 Parameters 

7231 ---------- 

7232 x : 1-D array or sequence 

7233 Array or sequence containing the data 

7234 

7235 %(Spectral)s 

7236 

7237 %(PSD)s 

7238 

7239 noverlap : int, default: 0 (no overlap) 

7240 The number of points of overlap between segments. 

7241 

7242 Fc : int, default: 0 

7243 The center frequency of *x*, which offsets the x extents of the 

7244 plot to reflect the frequency range used when a signal is acquired 

7245 and then filtered and downsampled to baseband. 

7246 

7247 return_line : bool, default: False 

7248 Whether to include the line object plotted in the returned values. 

7249 

7250 Returns 

7251 ------- 

7252 Pxx : 1-D array 

7253 The values for the power spectrum :math:`P_{xx}` before scaling 

7254 (real valued). 

7255 

7256 freqs : 1-D array 

7257 The frequencies corresponding to the elements in *Pxx*. 

7258 

7259 line : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` 

7260 The line created by this function. 

7261 Only returned if *return_line* is True. 

7262 

7263 Other Parameters 

7264 ---------------- 

7265 data : indexable object, optional 

7266 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

7267 

7268 **kwargs 

7269 Keyword arguments control the `.Line2D` properties: 

7270 

7271 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s 

7272 

7273 See Also 

7274 -------- 

7275 specgram 

7276 Differs in the default overlap; in not returning the mean of the 

7277 segment periodograms; in returning the times of the segments; and 

7278 in plotting a colormap instead of a line. 

7279 magnitude_spectrum 

7280 Plots the magnitude spectrum. 

7281 csd 

7282 Plots the spectral density between two signals. 

7283 

7284 Notes 

7285 ----- 

7286 For plotting, the power is plotted as 

7287 :math:`10\log_{10}(P_{xx})` for decibels, though *Pxx* itself 

7288 is returned. 

7289 

7290 References 

7291 ---------- 

7292 Bendat & Piersol -- Random Data: Analysis and Measurement Procedures, 

7293 John Wiley & Sons (1986) 

7294 """ 

7295 if Fc is None: 7295 ↛ 7298line 7295 didn't jump to line 7298, because the condition on line 7295 was never false

7296 Fc = 0 

7297 

7298 pxx, freqs = mlab.psd(x=x, NFFT=NFFT, Fs=Fs, detrend=detrend, 

7299 window=window, noverlap=noverlap, pad_to=pad_to, 

7300 sides=sides, scale_by_freq=scale_by_freq) 

7301 freqs += Fc 

7302 

7303 if scale_by_freq in (None, True): 7303 ↛ 7306line 7303 didn't jump to line 7306, because the condition on line 7303 was never false

7304 psd_units = 'dB/Hz' 

7305 else: 

7306 psd_units = 'dB' 

7307 

7308 line = self.plot(freqs, 10 * np.log10(pxx), **kwargs) 

7309 self.set_xlabel('Frequency') 

7310 self.set_ylabel('Power Spectral Density (%s)' % psd_units) 

7311 self.grid(True) 

7312 

7313 vmin, vmax = self.get_ybound() 

7314 step = max(10 * int(np.log10(vmax - vmin)), 1) 

7315 ticks = np.arange(math.floor(vmin), math.ceil(vmax) + 1, step) 

7316 self.set_yticks(ticks) 

7317 

7318 if return_line is None or not return_line: 

7319 return pxx, freqs 

7320 else: 

7321 return pxx, freqs, line 

7322 

7323 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x", "y"], label_namer="y") 

7324 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

7325 def csd(self, x, y, NFFT=None, Fs=None, Fc=None, detrend=None, 

7326 window=None, noverlap=None, pad_to=None, 

7327 sides=None, scale_by_freq=None, return_line=None, **kwargs): 

7328 r""" 

7329 Plot the cross-spectral density. 

7330 

7331 The cross spectral density :math:`P_{xy}` by Welch's average 

7332 periodogram method. The vectors *x* and *y* are divided into 

7333 *NFFT* length segments. Each segment is detrended by function 

7334 *detrend* and windowed by function *window*. *noverlap* gives 

7335 the length of the overlap between segments. The product of 

7336 the direct FFTs of *x* and *y* are averaged over each segment 

7337 to compute :math:`P_{xy}`, with a scaling to correct for power 

7338 loss due to windowing. 

7339 

7340 If len(*x*) < *NFFT* or len(*y*) < *NFFT*, they will be zero 

7341 padded to *NFFT*. 

7342 

7343 Parameters 

7344 ---------- 

7345 x, y : 1-D arrays or sequences 

7346 Arrays or sequences containing the data. 

7347 

7348 %(Spectral)s 

7349 

7350 %(PSD)s 

7351 

7352 noverlap : int, default: 0 (no overlap) 

7353 The number of points of overlap between segments. 

7354 

7355 Fc : int, default: 0 

7356 The center frequency of *x*, which offsets the x extents of the 

7357 plot to reflect the frequency range used when a signal is acquired 

7358 and then filtered and downsampled to baseband. 

7359 

7360 return_line : bool, default: False 

7361 Whether to include the line object plotted in the returned values. 

7362 

7363 Returns 

7364 ------- 

7365 Pxy : 1-D array 

7366 The values for the cross spectrum :math:`P_{xy}` before scaling 

7367 (complex valued). 

7368 

7369 freqs : 1-D array 

7370 The frequencies corresponding to the elements in *Pxy*. 

7371 

7372 line : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` 

7373 The line created by this function. 

7374 Only returned if *return_line* is True. 

7375 

7376 Other Parameters 

7377 ---------------- 

7378 data : indexable object, optional 

7379 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

7380 

7381 **kwargs 

7382 Keyword arguments control the `.Line2D` properties: 

7383 

7384 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s 

7385 

7386 See Also 

7387 -------- 

7388 psd : is equivalent to setting ``y = x``. 

7389 

7390 Notes 

7391 ----- 

7392 For plotting, the power is plotted as 

7393 :math:`10 \log_{10}(P_{xy})` for decibels, though :math:`P_{xy}` itself 

7394 is returned. 

7395 

7396 References 

7397 ---------- 

7398 Bendat & Piersol -- Random Data: Analysis and Measurement Procedures, 

7399 John Wiley & Sons (1986) 

7400 """ 

7401 if Fc is None: 7401 ↛ 7404line 7401 didn't jump to line 7404, because the condition on line 7401 was never false

7402 Fc = 0 

7403 

7404 pxy, freqs = mlab.csd(x=x, y=y, NFFT=NFFT, Fs=Fs, detrend=detrend, 

7405 window=window, noverlap=noverlap, pad_to=pad_to, 

7406 sides=sides, scale_by_freq=scale_by_freq) 

7407 # pxy is complex 

7408 freqs += Fc 

7409 

7410 line = self.plot(freqs, 10 * np.log10(np.abs(pxy)), **kwargs) 

7411 self.set_xlabel('Frequency') 

7412 self.set_ylabel('Cross Spectrum Magnitude (dB)') 

7413 self.grid(True) 

7414 

7415 vmin, vmax = self.get_ybound() 

7416 step = max(10 * int(np.log10(vmax - vmin)), 1) 

7417 ticks = np.arange(math.floor(vmin), math.ceil(vmax) + 1, step) 

7418 self.set_yticks(ticks) 

7419 

7420 if return_line is None or not return_line: 

7421 return pxy, freqs 

7422 else: 

7423 return pxy, freqs, line 

7424 

7425 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x"]) 

7426 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

7427 def magnitude_spectrum(self, x, Fs=None, Fc=None, window=None, 

7428 pad_to=None, sides=None, scale=None, 

7429 **kwargs): 

7430 """ 

7431 Plot the magnitude spectrum. 

7432 

7433 Compute the magnitude spectrum of *x*. Data is padded to a 

7434 length of *pad_to* and the windowing function *window* is applied to 

7435 the signal. 

7436 

7437 Parameters 

7438 ---------- 

7439 x : 1-D array or sequence 

7440 Array or sequence containing the data. 

7441 

7442 %(Spectral)s 

7443 

7444 %(Single_Spectrum)s 

7445 

7446 scale : {'default', 'linear', 'dB'} 

7447 The scaling of the values in the *spec*. 'linear' is no scaling. 

7448 'dB' returns the values in dB scale, i.e., the dB amplitude 

7449 (20 * log10). 'default' is 'linear'. 

7450 

7451 Fc : int, default: 0 

7452 The center frequency of *x*, which offsets the x extents of the 

7453 plot to reflect the frequency range used when a signal is acquired 

7454 and then filtered and downsampled to baseband. 

7455 

7456 Returns 

7457 ------- 

7458 spectrum : 1-D array 

7459 The values for the magnitude spectrum before scaling (real valued). 

7460 

7461 freqs : 1-D array 

7462 The frequencies corresponding to the elements in *spectrum*. 

7463 

7464 line : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` 

7465 The line created by this function. 

7466 

7467 Other Parameters 

7468 ---------------- 

7469 data : indexable object, optional 

7470 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

7471 

7472 **kwargs 

7473 Keyword arguments control the `.Line2D` properties: 

7474 

7475 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s 

7476 

7477 See Also 

7478 -------- 

7479 psd 

7480 Plots the power spectral density. 

7481 angle_spectrum 

7482 Plots the angles of the corresponding frequencies. 

7483 phase_spectrum 

7484 Plots the phase (unwrapped angle) of the corresponding frequencies. 

7485 specgram 

7486 Can plot the magnitude spectrum of segments within the signal in a 

7487 colormap. 

7488 """ 

7489 if Fc is None: 7489 ↛ 7492line 7489 didn't jump to line 7492, because the condition on line 7489 was never false

7490 Fc = 0 

7491 

7492 spec, freqs = mlab.magnitude_spectrum(x=x, Fs=Fs, window=window, 

7493 pad_to=pad_to, sides=sides) 

7494 freqs += Fc 

7495 

7496 yunits = _api.check_getitem( 

7497 {None: 'energy', 'default': 'energy', 'linear': 'energy', 

7498 'dB': 'dB'}, 

7499 scale=scale) 

7500 if yunits == 'energy': 

7501 Z = spec 

7502 else: # yunits == 'dB' 

7503 Z = 20. * np.log10(spec) 

7504 

7505 line, = self.plot(freqs, Z, **kwargs) 

7506 self.set_xlabel('Frequency') 

7507 self.set_ylabel('Magnitude (%s)' % yunits) 

7508 

7509 return spec, freqs, line 

7510 

7511 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x"]) 

7512 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

7513 def angle_spectrum(self, x, Fs=None, Fc=None, window=None, 

7514 pad_to=None, sides=None, **kwargs): 

7515 """ 

7516 Plot the angle spectrum. 

7517 

7518 Compute the angle spectrum (wrapped phase spectrum) of *x*. 

7519 Data is padded to a length of *pad_to* and the windowing function 

7520 *window* is applied to the signal. 

7521 

7522 Parameters 

7523 ---------- 

7524 x : 1-D array or sequence 

7525 Array or sequence containing the data. 

7526 

7527 %(Spectral)s 

7528 

7529 %(Single_Spectrum)s 

7530 

7531 Fc : int, default: 0 

7532 The center frequency of *x*, which offsets the x extents of the 

7533 plot to reflect the frequency range used when a signal is acquired 

7534 and then filtered and downsampled to baseband. 

7535 

7536 Returns 

7537 ------- 

7538 spectrum : 1-D array 

7539 The values for the angle spectrum in radians (real valued). 

7540 

7541 freqs : 1-D array 

7542 The frequencies corresponding to the elements in *spectrum*. 

7543 

7544 line : `~matplotlib.lines.Line2D` 

7545 The line created by this function. 

7546 

7547 Other Parameters 

7548 ---------------- 

7549 data : indexable object, optional 

7550 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

7551 

7552 **kwargs 

7553 Keyword arguments control the `.Line2D` properties: 

7554 

7555 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s 

7556 

7557 See Also 

7558 -------- 

7559 magnitude_spectrum 

7560 Plots the magnitudes of the corresponding frequencies. 

7561 phase_spectrum 

7562 Plots the unwrapped version of this function. 

7563 specgram 

7564 Can plot the angle spectrum of segments within the signal in a 

7565 colormap. 

7566 """ 

7567 if Fc is None: 7567 ↛ 7570line 7567 didn't jump to line 7570, because the condition on line 7567 was never false

7568 Fc = 0 

7569 

7570 spec, freqs = mlab.angle_spectrum(x=x, Fs=Fs, window=window, 

7571 pad_to=pad_to, sides=sides) 

7572 freqs += Fc 

7573 

7574 lines = self.plot(freqs, spec, **kwargs) 

7575 self.set_xlabel('Frequency') 

7576 self.set_ylabel('Angle (radians)') 

7577 

7578 return spec, freqs, lines[0] 

7579 

7580 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x"])

7582 def phase_spectrum(self, x, Fs=None, Fc=None, window=None,

7584 """ 

7585 Plot the phase spectrum. 

7586 

7587 Compute the phase spectrum (unwrapped angle spectrum) of *x*. 

7588 Data is padded to a length of *pad_to* and the windowing function 

7589 *window* is applied to the signal. 

7590 

7591 Parameters 

7592 ---------- 

7593 x : 1-D array or sequence 

7594 Array or sequence containing the data

7597

7600 Fc : int, default: 0 

7601 The center frequency of *x*, which offsets the x extents of the 

7602 plot to reflect the frequency range used when a signal is acquired 

7603 and then filtered and downsampled to baseband.

7648 

7649 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x", "y"]) 

7650 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

7651 def cohere(self, x, y, NFFT=256, Fs=2, Fc=0, detrend=mlab.detrend_none, 

7652 window=mlab.window_hanning, noverlap=0, pad_to=None, 

7653 sides='default', scale_by_freq=None, **kwargs): 

7654 r""" 

7655 Plot the coherence between *x* and *y*. 

7656 

7657 Coherence is the normalized cross spectral density: 

7658 

7659 .. math:: 

7660 

7661 C_{xy} = \frac{|P_{xy}|^2}{P_{xx}P_{yy}} 

7662 

7663 Parameters 

7664 ---------- 

7665 %(Spectral)s 

7666 

7667 %(PSD)s 

7668 

7669 noverlap : int, default: 0 (no overlap) 

7670 The number of points of overlap between blocks. 

7671 

7672 Fc : int, default: 0 

7673 The center frequency of *x*, which offsets the x extents of the 

7674 plot to reflect the frequency range used when a signal is acquired 

7675 and then filtered and downsampled to baseband. 

7676 

7677 Returns 

7678 ------- 

7679 Cxy : 1-D array 

7680 The coherence vector. 

7681 

7682 freqs : 1-D array 

7683 The frequencies for the elements in *Cxy*. 

7684 

7685 Other Parameters 

7686 ---------------- 

7687 data : indexable object, optional 

7688 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

7689 

7690 **kwargs 

7691 Keyword arguments control the `.Line2D` properties: 

7692 

7693 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s 

7694 

7695 References 

7696 ---------- 

7697 Bendat & Piersol -- Random Data: Analysis and Measurement Procedures, 

7698 John Wiley & Sons (1986) 

7699 """ 

7700 cxy, freqs = mlab.cohere(x=x, y=y, NFFT=NFFT, Fs=Fs, detrend=detrend, 

7701 window=window, noverlap=noverlap, 

7702 scale_by_freq=scale_by_freq, sides=sides, 

7703 pad_to=pad_to) 

7704 freqs += Fc 

7705 

7706 self.plot(freqs, cxy, **kwargs) 

7707 self.set_xlabel('Frequency') 

7708 self.set_ylabel('Coherence') 

7709 self.grid(True) 

7710 

7711 return cxy, freqs 

7712 

7713 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["x"]) 

7714 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

7715 def specgram(self, x, NFFT=None, Fs=None, Fc=None, detrend=None, 

7716 window=None, noverlap=None, 

7717 cmap=None, xextent=None, pad_to=None, sides=None, 

7718 scale_by_freq=None, mode=None, scale=None, 

7719 vmin=None, vmax=None, **kwargs): 

7720 """ 

7721 Plot a spectrogram. 

7722 

7723 Compute and plot a spectrogram of data in *x*. Data are split into 

7724 *NFFT* length segments and the spectrum of each section is 

7725 computed. The windowing function *window* is applied to each 

7726 segment, and the amount of overlap of each segment is 

7727 specified with *noverlap*. The spectrogram is plotted as a colormap 

7728 (using imshow). 

7729 

7730 Parameters 

7731 ---------- 

7732 x : 1-D array or sequence 

7733 Array or sequence containing the data. 

7734 

7735 %(Spectral)s 

7736 

7737 %(PSD)s 

7738 

7739 mode : {'default', 'psd', 'magnitude', 'angle', 'phase'} 

7740 What sort of spectrum to use. Default is 'psd', which takes the 

7741 power spectral density. 'magnitude' returns the magnitude 

7742 spectrum. 'angle' returns the phase spectrum without unwrapping. 

7743 'phase' returns the phase spectrum with unwrapping. 

7744 

7745 noverlap : int, default: 128 

7746 The number of points of overlap between blocks. 

7747 

7748 scale : {'default', 'linear', 'dB'} 

7749 The scaling of the values in the *spec*. 'linear' is no scaling. 

7750 'dB' returns the values in dB scale. When *mode* is 'psd', 

7751 this is dB power (10 * log10). Otherwise, this is dB amplitude 

7752 (20 * log10). 'default' is 'dB' if *mode* is 'psd' or 

7753 'magnitude' and 'linear' otherwise. This must be 'linear' 

7754 if *mode* is 'angle' or 'phase'. 

7755 

7756 Fc : int, default: 0 

7757 The center frequency of *x*, which offsets the x extents of the 

7758 plot to reflect the frequency range used when a signal is acquired 

7759 and then filtered and downsampled to baseband. 

7760 

7761 cmap : `.Colormap`, default: :rc:`image.cmap` 

7762 

7763 xextent : *None* or (xmin, xmax) 

7764 The image extent along the x-axis. The default sets *xmin* to the 

7765 left border of the first bin (*spectrum* column) and *xmax* to the 

7766 right border of the last bin. Note that for *noverlap>0* the width 

7767 of the bins is smaller than those of the segments. 

7768 

7769 data : indexable object, optional 

7770 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

7771 

7772 **kwargs 

7773 Additional keyword arguments are passed on to `~.axes.Axes.imshow` 

7774 which makes the specgram image. The origin keyword argument 

7775 is not supported. 

7776 

7777 Returns 

7778 ------- 

7779 spectrum : 2D array 

7780 Columns are the periodograms of successive segments. 

7781 

7782 freqs : 1-D array 

7783 The frequencies corresponding to the rows in *spectrum*. 

7784 

7785 t : 1-D array 

7786 The times corresponding to midpoints of segments (i.e., the columns 

7787 in *spectrum*). 

7788 

7789 im : `.AxesImage` 

7790 The image created by imshow containing the spectrogram. 

7791 

7792 See Also 

7793 -------- 

7794 psd 

7795 Differs in the default overlap; in returning the mean of the 

7796 segment periodograms; in not returning times; and in generating a 

7797 line plot instead of colormap. 

7798 magnitude_spectrum 

7799 A single spectrum, similar to having a single segment when *mode* 

7800 is 'magnitude'. Plots a line instead of a colormap. 

7801 angle_spectrum 

7802 A single spectrum, similar to having a single segment when *mode* 

7803 is 'angle'. Plots a line instead of a colormap. 

7804 phase_spectrum 

7805 A single spectrum, similar to having a single segment when *mode* 

7806 is 'phase'. Plots a line instead of a colormap. 

7807 

7808 Notes 

7809 ----- 

7810 The parameters *detrend* and *scale_by_freq* do only apply when *mode* 

7811 is set to 'psd'. 

7812 """ 

7813 if NFFT is None: 

7814 NFFT = 256 # same default as in mlab.specgram() 

7815 if Fc is None: 7815 ↛ 7817line 7815 didn't jump to line 7817, because the condition on line 7815 was never false

7816 Fc = 0 # same default as in mlab._spectral_helper() 

7817 if noverlap is None: 

7818 noverlap = 128 # same default as in mlab.specgram() 

7819 if Fs is None: 

7820 Fs = 2 # same default as in mlab._spectral_helper() 

7821 

7822 if mode == 'complex': 7822 ↛ 7823line 7822 didn't jump to line 7823, because the condition on line 7822 was never true

7823 raise ValueError('Cannot plot a complex specgram') 

7824 

7825 if scale is None or scale == 'default': 

7826 if mode in ['angle', 'phase']: 

7827 scale = 'linear' 

7828 else: 

7829 scale = 'dB' 

7830 elif mode in ['angle', 'phase'] and scale == 'dB': 

7831 raise ValueError('Cannot use dB scale with angle or phase mode') 

7832 

7833 spec, freqs, t = mlab.specgram(x=x, NFFT=NFFT, Fs=Fs, 

7834 detrend=detrend, window=window, 

7835 noverlap=noverlap, pad_to=pad_to, 

7836 sides=sides, 

7837 scale_by_freq=scale_by_freq, 

7838 mode=mode) 

7839 

7840 if scale == 'linear': 

7841 Z = spec 

7842 elif scale == 'dB': 7842 ↛ 7848line 7842 didn't jump to line 7848, because the condition on line 7842 was never false

7843 if mode is None or mode == 'default' or mode == 'psd': 

7844 Z = 10. * np.log10(spec) 

7845 else: 

7846 Z = 20. * np.log10(spec) 

7847 else: 

7848 raise ValueError(f'Unknown scale {scale!r}') 

7849 

7850 Z = np.flipud(Z) 

7851 

7852 if xextent is None: 7852 ↛ 7856line 7852 didn't jump to line 7856, because the condition on line 7852 was never false

7853 # padding is needed for first and last segment: 

7854 pad_xextent = (NFFT-noverlap) / Fs / 2 

7855 xextent = np.min(t) - pad_xextent, np.max(t) + pad_xextent 

7856 xmin, xmax = xextent 

7857 freqs += Fc 

7858 extent = xmin, xmax, freqs[0], freqs[-1] 

7859 

7860 if 'origin' in kwargs: 

7861 raise _api.kwarg_error("specgram", "origin") 

7862 

7863 im = self.imshow(Z, cmap, extent=extent, vmin=vmin, vmax=vmax, 

7864 origin='upper', **kwargs) 

7865 self.axis('auto') 

7866 

7867 return spec, freqs, t, im 

7868 

7869 @_docstring.dedent_interpd 

7870 def spy(self, Z, precision=0, marker=None, markersize=None, 

7871 aspect='equal', origin="upper", **kwargs): 

7872 """ 

7873 Plot the sparsity pattern of a 2D array. 

7874 

7875 This visualizes the non-zero values of the array. 

7876 

7877 Two plotting styles are available: image and marker. Both 

7878 are available for full arrays, but only the marker style 

7879 works for `scipy.sparse.spmatrix` instances. 

7880 

7881 **Image style** 

7882 

7883 If *marker* and *markersize* are *None*, `~.Axes.imshow` is used. Any 

7884 extra remaining keyword arguments are passed to this method. 

7885 

7886 **Marker style** 

7887 

7888 If *Z* is a `scipy.sparse.spmatrix` or *marker* or *markersize* are 

7889 *None*, a `.Line2D` object will be returned with the value of marker 

7890 determining the marker type, and any remaining keyword arguments 

7891 passed to `~.Axes.plot`. 

7892 

7893 Parameters 

7894 ---------- 

7895 Z : (M, N) array-like 

7896 The array to be plotted. 

7897 

7898 precision : float or 'present', default: 0 

7899 If *precision* is 0, any non-zero value will be plotted. Otherwise, 

7900 values of :math:`|Z| > precision` will be plotted. 

7901 

7902 For `scipy.sparse.spmatrix` instances, you can also 

7903 pass 'present'. In this case any value present in the array 

7904 will be plotted, even if it is identically zero. 

7905 

7906 aspect : {'equal', 'auto', None} or float, default: 'equal' 

7907 The aspect ratio of the Axes. This parameter is particularly 

7908 relevant for images since it determines whether data pixels are 

7909 square. 

7910 

7911 This parameter is a shortcut for explicitly calling 

7912 `.Axes.set_aspect`. See there for further details. 

7913 

7914 - 'equal': Ensures an aspect ratio of 1. Pixels will be square. 

7915 - 'auto': The Axes is kept fixed and the aspect is adjusted so 

7916 that the data fit in the Axes. In general, this will result in 

7917 non-square pixels. 

7918 - *None*: Use :rc:`image.aspect`. 

7919 

7920 origin : {'upper', 'lower'}, default: :rc:`image.origin` 

7921 Place the [0, 0] index of the array in the upper left or lower left 

7922 corner of the Axes. The convention 'upper' is typically used for 

7923 matrices and images. 

7924 

7925 Returns 

7926 ------- 

7927 `~matplotlib.image.AxesImage` or `.Line2D` 

7928 The return type depends on the plotting style (see above). 

7929 

7930 Other Parameters 

7931 ---------------- 

7932 **kwargs 

7933 The supported additional parameters depend on the plotting style. 

7934 

7935 For the image style, you can pass the following additional 

7936 parameters of `~.Axes.imshow`: 

7937 

7938 - *cmap* 

7939 - *alpha* 

7940 - *url* 

7941 - any `.Artist` properties (passed on to the `.AxesImage`) 

7942 

7943 For the marker style, you can pass any `.Line2D` property except 

7944 for *linestyle*: 

7945 

7946 %(Line2D:kwdoc)s 

7947 """ 

7948 if marker is None and markersize is None and hasattr(Z, 'tocoo'): 7948 ↛ 7949line 7948 didn't jump to line 7949, because the condition on line 7948 was never true

7949 marker = 's' 

7950 _api.check_in_list(["upper", "lower"], origin=origin) 

7951 if marker is None and markersize is None: 

7952 Z = np.asarray(Z) 

7953 mask = np.abs(Z) > precision 

7954 

7955 if 'cmap' not in kwargs: 7955 ↛ 7958line 7955 didn't jump to line 7958, because the condition on line 7955 was never false

7956 kwargs['cmap'] = mcolors.ListedColormap(['w', 'k'], 

7957 name='binary') 

7958 if 'interpolation' in kwargs: 

7959 raise _api.kwarg_error("spy", "interpolation") 

7960 if 'norm' not in kwargs: 7960 ↛ 7962line 7960 didn't jump to line 7962, because the condition on line 7960 was never false

7961 kwargs['norm'] = mcolors.NoNorm() 

7962 ret = self.imshow(mask, interpolation='nearest', 

7963 aspect=aspect, origin=origin, 

7964 **kwargs) 

7965 else: 

7966 if hasattr(Z, 'tocoo'): 7966 ↛ 7967line 7966 didn't jump to line 7967, because the condition on line 7966 was never true

7967 c = Z.tocoo() 

7968 if precision == 'present': 

7969 y = c.row 

7970 x = c.col 

7971 else: 

7972 nonzero = np.abs(c.data) > precision 

7973 y = c.row[nonzero] 

7974 x = c.col[nonzero] 

7975 else: 

7976 Z = np.asarray(Z) 

7977 nonzero = np.abs(Z) > precision 

7978 y, x = np.nonzero(nonzero) 

7979 if marker is None: 7979 ↛ 7980line 7979 didn't jump to line 7980, because the condition on line 7979 was never true

7980 marker = 's' 

7981 if markersize is None: 7981 ↛ 7983line 7981 didn't jump to line 7983, because the condition on line 7981 was never false

7982 markersize = 10 

7983 if 'linestyle' in kwargs: 

7984 raise _api.kwarg_error("spy", "linestyle") 

7985 ret = mlines.Line2D( 

7986 x, y, linestyle='None', marker=marker, markersize=markersize, 

7987 **kwargs) 

7988 self.add_line(ret) 

7989 nr, nc = Z.shape 

7990 self.set_xlim(-0.5, nc - 0.5) 

7991 if origin == "upper": 7991 ↛ 7992line 7991 didn't jump to line 7992, because the condition on line 7991 was never true

7992 self.set_ylim(nr - 0.5, -0.5) 

7993 else: 

7994 self.set_ylim(-0.5, nr - 0.5) 

7995 self.set_aspect(aspect) 

7996 self.title.set_y(1.05) 

7997 if origin == "upper": 

7998 self.xaxis.tick_top() 

7999 else: # lower 

8000 self.xaxis.tick_bottom() 

8001 self.xaxis.set_ticks_position('both') 

8002 self.xaxis.set_major_locator( 

8003 mticker.MaxNLocator(nbins=9, steps=[1, 2, 5, 10], integer=True)) 

8004 self.yaxis.set_major_locator( 

8005 mticker.MaxNLocator(nbins=9, steps=[1, 2, 5, 10], integer=True)) 

8006 return ret 

8007 

8008 def matshow(self, Z, **kwargs): 

8009 """ 

8010 Plot the values of a 2D matrix or array as color-coded image. 

8011 

8012 The matrix will be shown the way it would be printed, with the first 

8013 row at the top. Row and column numbering is zero-based. 

8014 

8015 Parameters 

8016 ---------- 

8017 Z : (M, N) array-like 

8018 The matrix to be displayed. 

8019 

8020 Returns 

8021 ------- 

8022 `~matplotlib.image.AxesImage` 

8023 

8024 Other Parameters 

8025 ---------------- 

8026 **kwargs : `~matplotlib.axes.Axes.imshow` arguments 

8027 

8028 See Also 

8029 -------- 

8030 imshow : More general function to plot data on a 2D regular raster. 

8031 

8032 Notes 

8033 ----- 

8034 This is just a convenience function wrapping `.imshow` to set useful 

8035 defaults for displaying a matrix. In particular: 

8036 

8037 - Set ``origin='upper'``. 

8038 - Set ``interpolation='nearest'``. 

8039 - Set ``aspect='equal'``. 

8040 - Ticks are placed to the left and above. 

8041 - Ticks are formatted to show integer indices. 

8042 

8043 """ 

8044 Z = np.asanyarray(Z) 

8045 kw = {'origin': 'upper', 

8046 'interpolation': 'nearest', 

8047 'aspect': 'equal', # (already the imshow default) 

8048 **kwargs} 

8049 im = self.imshow(Z, **kw) 

8050 self.title.set_y(1.05) 

8051 self.xaxis.tick_top() 

8052 self.xaxis.set_ticks_position('both') 

8053 self.xaxis.set_major_locator( 

8054 mticker.MaxNLocator(nbins=9, steps=[1, 2, 5, 10], integer=True)) 

8055 self.yaxis.set_major_locator( 

8056 mticker.MaxNLocator(nbins=9, steps=[1, 2, 5, 10], integer=True)) 

8057 return im 

8058 

8059 @_preprocess_data(replace_names=["dataset"]) 

8060 def violinplot(self, dataset, positions=None, vert=True, widths=0.5, 

8061 showmeans=False, showextrema=True, showmedians=False, 

8062 quantiles=None, points=100, bw_method=None): 

8063 """ 

8064 Make a violin plot. 

8065 

8066 Make a violin plot for each column of *dataset* or each vector in 

8067 sequence *dataset*. Each filled area extends to represent the 

8068 entire data range, with optional lines at the mean, the median, 

8069 the minimum, the maximum, and user-specified quantiles. 

8070 

8071 Parameters 

8072 ---------- 

8073 dataset : Array or a sequence of vectors. 

8074 The input data. 

8075 

8076 positions : array-like, default: [1, 2, ..., n] 

8077 The positions of the violins. The ticks and limits are 

8078 automatically set to match the positions. 

8079 

8080 vert : bool, default: True. 

8081 If true, creates a vertical violin plot. 

8082 Otherwise, creates a horizontal violin plot. 

8083 

8084 widths : array-like, default: 0.5 

8085 Either a scalar or a vector that sets the maximal width of 

8086 each violin. The default is 0.5, which uses about half of the 

8087 available horizontal space. 

8088 

8089 showmeans : bool, default: False 

8090 If `True`, will toggle rendering of the means. 

8091 

8092 showextrema : bool, default: True 

8093 If `True`, will toggle rendering of the extrema. 

8094 

8095 showmedians : bool, default: False 

8096 If `True`, will toggle rendering of the medians. 

8097 

8098 quantiles : array-like, default: None 

8099 If not None, set a list of floats in interval [0, 1] for each violin, 

8100 which stands for the quantiles that will be rendered for that 

8101 violin. 

8102 

8103 points : int, default: 100 

8104 Defines the number of points to evaluate each of the 

8105 gaussian kernel density estimations at. 

8106 

8107 bw_method : str, scalar or callable, optional 

8108 The method used to calculate the estimator bandwidth. This can be 

8109 'scott', 'silverman', a scalar constant or a callable. If a 

8110 scalar, this will be used directly as `kde.factor`. If a 

8111 callable, it should take a `matplotlib.mlab.GaussianKDE` instance as 

8112 its only parameter and return a scalar. If None (default), 'scott' 

8113 is used. 

8114 

8115 data : indexable object, optional 

8116 DATA_PARAMETER_PLACEHOLDER 

8117 

8118 Returns 

8119 ------- 

8120 dict 

8121 A dictionary mapping each component of the violinplot to a 

8122 list of the corresponding collection instances created. The 

8123 dictionary has the following keys: 

8124 

8125 - ``bodies``: A list of the `~.collections.PolyCollection` 

8126 instances containing the filled area of each violin. 

8127 

8128 - ``cmeans``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks 

8129 the mean values of each of the violin's distribution. 

8130 

8131 - ``cmins``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks 

8132 the bottom of each violin's distribution. 

8133 

8134 - ``cmaxes``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks 

8135 the top of each violin's distribution. 

8136 

8137 - ``cbars``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks 

8138 the centers of each violin's distribution. 

8139 

8140 - ``cmedians``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that 

8141 marks the median values of each of the violin's distribution. 

8142 

8143 - ``cquantiles``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance created 

8144 to identify the quantile values of each of the violin's 

8145 distribution. 

8146 

8147 """ 

8148 

8149 def _kde_method(X, coords): 

8150 # Unpack in case of e.g. Pandas or xarray object 

8151 X = cbook._unpack_to_numpy(X) 

8152 # fallback gracefully if the vector contains only one value 

8153 if np.all(X[0] == X): 

8154 return (X[0] == coords).astype(float) 

8155 kde = mlab.GaussianKDE(X, bw_method) 

8156 return kde.evaluate(coords) 

8157 

8158 vpstats = cbook.violin_stats(dataset, _kde_method, points=points, 

8159 quantiles=quantiles) 

8160 return self.violin(vpstats, positions=positions, vert=vert, 

8161 widths=widths, showmeans=showmeans, 

8162 showextrema=showextrema, showmedians=showmedians) 

8163 

8164 def violin(self, vpstats, positions=None, vert=True, widths=0.5, 

8165 showmeans=False, showextrema=True, showmedians=False): 

8166 """ 

8167 Drawing function for violin plots. 

8168 

8169 Draw a violin plot for each column of *vpstats*. Each filled area 

8170 extends to represent the entire data range, with optional lines at the 

8171 mean, the median, the minimum, the maximum, and the quantiles values. 

8172 

8173 Parameters 

8174 ---------- 

8175 vpstats : list of dicts 

8176 A list of dictionaries containing stats for each violin plot. 

8177 Required keys are: 

8178 

8179 - ``coords``: A list of scalars containing the coordinates that 

8180 the violin's kernel density estimate were evaluated at. 

8181 

8182 - ``vals``: A list of scalars containing the values of the 

8183 kernel density estimate at each of the coordinates given 

8184 in *coords*. 

8185 

8186 - ``mean``: The mean value for this violin's dataset. 

8187 

8188 - ``median``: The median value for this violin's dataset. 

8189 

8190 - ``min``: The minimum value for this violin's dataset. 

8191 

8192 - ``max``: The maximum value for this violin's dataset. 

8193 

8194 Optional keys are: 

8195 

8196 - ``quantiles``: A list of scalars containing the quantile values 

8197 for this violin's dataset. 

8198 

8199 positions : array-like, default: [1, 2, ..., n] 

8200 The positions of the violins. The ticks and limits are 

8201 automatically set to match the positions. 

8202 

8203 vert : bool, default: True. 

8204 If true, plots the violins vertically. 

8205 Otherwise, plots the violins horizontally. 

8206 

8207 widths : array-like, default: 0.5 

8208 Either a scalar or a vector that sets the maximal width of 

8209 each violin. The default is 0.5, which uses about half of the 

8210 available horizontal space. 

8211 

8212 showmeans : bool, default: False 

8213 If true, will toggle rendering of the means. 

8214 

8215 showextrema : bool, default: True 

8216 If true, will toggle rendering of the extrema. 

8217 

8218 showmedians : bool, default: False 

8219 If true, will toggle rendering of the medians. 

8220 

8221 Returns 

8222 ------- 

8223 dict 

8224 A dictionary mapping each component of the violinplot to a 

8225 list of the corresponding collection instances created. The 

8226 dictionary has the following keys: 

8227 

8228 - ``bodies``: A list of the `~.collections.PolyCollection` 

8229 instances containing the filled area of each violin. 

8230 

8231 - ``cmeans``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks 

8232 the mean values of each of the violin's distribution. 

8233 

8234 - ``cmins``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks 

8235 the bottom of each violin's distribution. 

8236 

8237 - ``cmaxes``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks 

8238 the top of each violin's distribution. 

8239 

8240 - ``cbars``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that marks 

8241 the centers of each violin's distribution. 

8242 

8243 - ``cmedians``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance that 

8244 marks the median values of each of the violin's distribution. 

8245 

8246 - ``cquantiles``: A `~.collections.LineCollection` instance created 

8247 to identify the quantiles values of each of the violin's 

8248 distribution. 

8249 """ 

8250 

8251 # Statistical quantities to be plotted on the violins 

8252 means = [] 

8253 mins = [] 

8254 maxes = [] 

8255 medians = [] 

8256 quantiles = [] 

8257 

8258 qlens = [] # Number of quantiles in each dataset. 

8259 

8260 artists = {} # Collections to be returned 

8261 

8262 N = len(vpstats) 

8263 datashape_message = ("List of violinplot statistics and `{0}` " 

8264 "values must have the same length") 

8265 

8266 # Validate positions 

8267 if positions is None: 

8268 positions = range(1, N + 1) 

8269 elif len(positions) != N: 

8270 raise ValueError(datashape_message.format("positions")) 

8271 

8272 # Validate widths 

8273 if np.isscalar(widths): 

8274 widths = [widths] * N 

8275 elif len(widths) != N: 8275 ↛ 8279line 8275 didn't jump to line 8279, because the condition on line 8275 was never false

8276 raise ValueError(datashape_message.format("widths")) 

8277 

8278 # Calculate ranges for statistics lines (shape (2, N)). 

8279 line_ends = [[-0.25], [0.25]] * np.array(widths) + positions 

8280 

8281 # Colors. 

8282 if mpl.rcParams['_internal.classic_mode']: 8282 ↛ 8286line 8282 didn't jump to line 8286, because the condition on line 8282 was never false

8283 fillcolor = 'y' 

8284 linecolor = 'r' 

8285 else: 

8286 fillcolor = linecolor = self._get_lines.get_next_color() 

8287 

8288 # Check whether we are rendering vertically or horizontally 

8289 if vert: 

8290 fill = self.fill_betweenx 

8291 perp_lines = functools.partial(self.hlines, colors=linecolor) 

8292 par_lines = functools.partial(self.vlines, colors=linecolor) 

8293 else: 

8294 fill = self.fill_between 

8295 perp_lines = functools.partial(self.vlines, colors=linecolor) 

8296 par_lines = functools.partial(self.hlines, colors=linecolor) 

8297 

8298 # Render violins 

8299 bodies = [] 

8300 for stats, pos, width in zip(vpstats, positions, widths): 

8301 # The 0.5 factor reflects the fact that we plot from v-p to v+p. 

8302 vals = np.array(stats['vals']) 

8303 vals = 0.5 * width * vals / vals.max() 

8304 bodies += [fill(stats['coords'], -vals + pos, vals + pos, 

8305 facecolor=fillcolor, alpha=0.3)] 

8306 means.append(stats['mean']) 

8307 mins.append(stats['min']) 

8308 maxes.append(stats['max']) 

8309 medians.append(stats['median']) 

8310 q = stats.get('quantiles') # a list of floats, or None 

8311 if q is None: 8311 ↛ 8312line 8311 didn't jump to line 8312, because the condition on line 8311 was never true

8312 q = [] 

8313 quantiles.extend(q) 

8314 qlens.append(len(q)) 

8315 artists['bodies'] = bodies 

8316 

8317 if showmeans: # Render means 

8318 artists['cmeans'] = perp_lines(means, *line_ends) 

8319 if showextrema: # Render extrema 

8320 artists['cmaxes'] = perp_lines(maxes, *line_ends) 

8321 artists['cmins'] = perp_lines(mins, *line_ends) 

8322 artists['cbars'] = par_lines(positions, mins, maxes) 

8323 if showmedians: # Render medians 

8324 artists['cmedians'] = perp_lines(medians, *line_ends) 

8325 if quantiles: # Render quantiles: each width is repeated qlen times. 

8326 artists['cquantiles'] = perp_lines( 

8327 quantiles, *np.repeat(line_ends, qlens, axis=1)) 

8328 

8329 return artists 

8330 

8331 # Methods that are entirely implemented in other modules. 

8332 

8333 table = mtable.table 

8334 

8335 # args can be either Y or y1, y2, ... and all should be replaced 

8336 stackplot = _preprocess_data()(mstack.stackplot) 

8337 

8338 streamplot = _preprocess_data( 

8339 replace_names=["x", "y", "u", "v", "start_points"])(mstream.streamplot) 

8340 

8341 tricontour = mtri.tricontour 

8342 tricontourf = mtri.tricontourf 

8343 tripcolor = mtri.tripcolor 

8344 triplot = mtri.triplot 

8345 

8346 def _get_aspect_ratio(self): 

8347 """ 

8348 Convenience method to calculate the aspect ratio of the axes in 

8349 the display coordinate system. 

8350 """ 

8351 figure_size = self.get_figure().get_size_inches() 

8352 ll, ur = self.get_position() * figure_size 

8353 width, height = ur - ll 

8354 return height / (width * self.get_data_ratio())
